## maania
 
 <i>n.</i> red tussock

>  Maori names for tussock varied from region to region. In one southern dialect, <i>wi</i> was used for silver tussock (furher north the same word was applied to rushes) and <i>patiti</i> seemed to be a general term for tall tussocks, with <i>maania</i> an alternative or the word for red tussock in particular. The Maniatoto (<i>maania</i> = blood, <i>toto</i> = plain) was formerly covered in red tussock. <i>(Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/40</i>)

## machine
 
 <i>n.</i> the mechanical or electric totalisator (See [totalisator](../T#totalisator))

>  An electric machine has a tremendous advantage over the old manual totalisator <i>(Aug 23, 1939,Taranaki Herald,3</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> shearing-machine

>  In sheds where machines are used.. the shearers to pay for combs and cutters at cost price. <i>(1906,Awards etc.,VII/625</i>)

>  With machines the average good shearer has 180 to 200 out at the end of the day. <i>(1945,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),3(6) : 24</i>)

>  The majority of the larger sheepowners ... have come to recognize the advantages of `machines' over `blades'. <i>(Sep 20, 1917,NZ Journal of Agriculture,134</i>)

>  <b>BOWEN</b> Relative quality of workmanship between blades and machines is a debatable point. <i>(1955,Wool Away!,9</i>)

>  <b>MILLS</b> This establishes the date [Nov. 17, 1900] of the change-over from blades to machines ... <i>(1960,Sheep-O,19</i>)

>  <b>DICK</b> `Blades or machines?' I asked. `Oh, we use the snow-comb - know it?' `Yes, yes I do. Where are you going? It's rather early, isn't it?' <i>(1964,High Country Family,144</i>)

>  `There's nothing spooking the sheep. They're quiet enough. It could be one of the boys setting up machines.' `None of them's got a ute like that,' I said. <i>(Dec 1986,Marist Messenger,34</i>) [NOTES: (Joy Cowley)]

>  Generally speaking, machines are used on the plains and blades in the back country. <i>(1945,Korero (AEWS Background Bulletin),III/6 : 23</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> the milking machine

## mackerel
 
 <i>n.</i> a common name for fishes resembling the northern hemisphere mackerel, esp. <i>Pneumatophorus</i> sp., the southern mackerel; and <i>Trachurus novae-zelandicae,</i> horse mackerel [early spellings mackarel, mackrel, etc.]

>  Another of our food fishes.. is the true mackerel (Scomber astralasicus) . . . The Maoris call the fish tawatawa. <i>(Jan 30, 1890,Otago Witness,18</i>)

>  The natives ... sold us ... as much fish as served all hands, they were of the Mackerel kind and as good as ever was eat. [f@n1] The Southern Mackerel, <i>Pneumatophorus colias. </i> <i>(Nov 8, 1769,Cook's Journals,1/195</i>)

>  ... a vast number of boats were on board almost loaded with macarel of 2 sorts, one exactly the same as is caught in England. [fn.] The Southern Mackerel, <i>Pneumatophorus colias</i> (Gm), is rather similar to the English species. The other sort was perhaps <i>Trachurus novae-zelandicae</i> Richardson. <i>(Nov 9, 1769,Banks Journal,2/428,1962 ed.</i>)

>  <b>YATE</b> ... in the mackerel-season, when several tribes go together to the little creeks where these fish frequent, and always succeed in capturing some hundreds of thousands before they return ibid 109 Their method of preparing the mackarel is different ... It is gutted, throughly washed with sea-water, and hung up to drain ... <i>(1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),71</i>) [NOTES: (Griffiths Collection)]

>  [mackarel] We got only fish, ... and these of various sorts, such as Shirks [check], Sting-rays, Breams, Mullet, Mackarel ... <i>(Dec 5, 1769,Cook's Journals,1/219,1955 ed.</i>)

>  <b>PARKINSON</b> [mackrel: attrib] ... native ... brought us a large quantity of fish, mostly of the mackrel kind, with a few John Dories. <i>(Nov 9, 1769,Journal,104</i>)

>  <b>POLACK</b> The<i> patiki</i> [a-acute], between the large flounder and the sole, is equally excellent with the European fish, as are also the <i>mackarel,</i> of which there are several varieties. <i>(1838,New Zealand  (Polack),1/322</i>)

>  <b>YATE</b> [mackarel] Those saltwater fish] most plentiful, and of greatest note, are, soles, mackarel, cod-fish, a species of salmon, whiting, snapper, mullet, bream, skate, gurnards, and a few smaller kinds, some not near so large as a sprat; with an abundance of crayfish, oysters, shrimps, prawns, muscles, and cockles. <i>Ibid.</i> 85 In their great fishing-expeditions for mackarel, all concerned in making or mending the nets, the ground upon which those nets are made, the river upon the banks of which the work goes on, are all in a state of sacredness; ... <i>(1835,New Zealand (various authors/titles),71</i>)

>  <b>HEAPHY</b> The bream, ling, gurnard, herring, sole, rock-cod, and a species of mackarel, are all in abundance, as are also many fish unknown elsewhere [than Wellington]. <i>(1842,New Zealand (Heaphy),49</i>)

>  <b>SHORTLAND</b> Mackerel were playing round us in large shoals, and were taken in great numbers by the crew. ... This fish was much larger than its namesake known on the shores of the West of England, and had not its delicate flavour. <i>(1851,Southern Districts of NZ,143</i>)

>  <b>TAYLOR</b> The <i>tamure</i>, or snapper, and the <i>kahawai</i>, mackeral, were taken with a hook ... <i>(1855,Te Ika a Maui,500</i>)

>  <b>HURSTHOUSE</b> ... the best [sea fish] are the Hapuka ..., the Moki, the Wharehou[ao-acute], the Patiki (a small plaice), the Kawai (a coarse common fish rising at the fly in tidal waters and sometimes dubbed salmon) a sort of mackerel, and some mullet, rock-cod, bastard-skate, and snapper. <i>(1857,New Zealand (various authors/titles),1/122</i>)

>  <b>HAY</b> We have, indeed, a wealth of fish in all the tidal waters. Sharks, schnapper, rock-cod, mackerel, mullet, herring, sole, halibut, albacore, barracouta, king-fish, and others. <i>(1882,Brighter Britain,2/230</i>)

The name `Skipjack' has also been applied however to at least half-a-dozen other species. <i>(1981,Fisherman's Bible,267</i>)

>  <b>SPEIGHT</b> The only true mackerels recorded from Canterbury are the Pacific Bonito <i>Sarda chiliensis</i>) and the large-scaled Tunny (<i>Gasterochisma melampus</i>) which may reach a length of 6 feet; but a related family includes the well-known Barracouta (<i>Thyrsites atun</i>), the King Barracouta, <i>Jordanidia solandrii</i> (often known locally as Kingfish, but not to be confused with the North Island Kingfish which is a form or Yellowtail) and the elongated, silvery-hued frost fish (<i>Lepidopus caudatus</i>) whose curious stranding habits can hardly yet be said to be satisfactorily explained. tentatively divided into 1. <i>Trachurus</i> spp. JACK MACKEREL HORSE MACKEREL a. <i>T novaezelandiae</i> of south-east Asian distribution; and b. <i>T. declivis</i> restricted to Australasia 2. <i>Scomber australasicus</i> and Indo-Pacific species, (COMMON) MACKEREL, BLUE MACKEREL, ENGLISH MACKEREL (from its similarity to the N. hemisphere species), FRIGATE MACKEREL, PACIFIC MACKEREL, SOUTHERN MACKEREL; 3. of uncertain attribution <i>(1927,Natural History of Canterbury,199</i>)

>  (Queen Charlotte Sound) ... the natives now and then brought Hake, ed. fn <i>Merluccius australis</i>.]Paracutas, [ed. fn <i>Thyrsites atun</i>.] a small sort of Mackarel, ed. fn <i>Scomber japonicus?.</i>] ... <i>(Feb 1777,Cook's Journals,3/808</i>) [NOTES: 1777 Feb Anderson's Journal in Cook Journals (1967) 3/808]

>  In smoky little back parlours [in Westport] friendly little groups meet to play `forty-fives' with uproarious oaths and much heavy thumping of the table. For [100] the uninitiated it may be stated that in this game the <i>five-fingers</i> (the five of the trump suit) beats all other cards. The trump suit order is five, jack, ace, king queen - all other suits begin with the king. Non-trump suits win high in red; low in black. Obviously the ace of diamonds is the lowest card in the pack unless diamonds are trumps, in which case it is the fourth best. The word "obviously' in the preceding sentence is a little optimistic - as the ace of hearts (the Maggy) is always the third best trump. It is credibly reported (a) that the game is of Irish origin (b) that there are no written rules (c) that the game can only be learned by playing it, and (d) it is as charactistic of Westport as whitebait or coal. <i>(1948,Our Own Country,99</i>)

## magistrate's court
 
 <i>n.</i> a local court, with powers to try minor cases (summary jurisdiction), and to hold preliminary inquiries into more serious cases which may go to a higher court. In New Zealand now called a District Court. [magistrate's or magistrates'?]

>  Generally known simply as magistrates (or SMs) they were legally qualified and exercised increasingly important judicial functions in magistrates courts These had a general jurisdiction - civil, criminal and domestic - that set them apart from English magistrates courts which mainly dealt with petty crime and were presided over by justices of the peace. Magistrates courts were renamed district courts and their presiding judges district court judges in 1981, but the term magistrate in New Zealand denoted stipendiary magistrates rather than justices of the peace, who were and are usually referred to simply as justices or JPs. <i>(Jan 1999,NZWords,1</i>)

>  In this land two infections assail all comers and vie with one another for first place. These are known as Malaria and Balkan Tap respectively. On the first we need not dwell, but a little information about the latter may be of interest. A similar infection has been met with elsewhere, and in Gyppo Land is known as `magnune', whilst away in our own sunny island I think `dippy' about covered it. Here we have a more or less insidious form of the disease, and no one with six months' residence to his credit may hope to escape. There are two varieties of the disease, malignant and benign. In the latter form the symptoms are easily recognised, and are amenable to treatment; but with the malignant type the victims, quite unconscious of infection, blindly affirm their condition to be normal, This form of the malady has several unfortunate features and is incurable. >  ... amongst which [in Queen Charlotte Sound] there are two [trees] that bear a sort of plumb the size of prunes, the one yellow [[Anderson's fn a] These are call'd Karraka by the natives.] and the other black, [[Anderson's fn b] Call'd Mai-tao by the Indians.] [1967 ed. comment sic [Tawa, <i>Beilschmiedia tawa</i>. ## maiden
 
 <i>n.</i> short for maiden ewe [applied to ewes the expression appears I think in 1853 Earp NZ (or in his NZ HBK)]

>  <b>NEWTON</b> MAIDEN EWES: Normally ewes are first bred from as two tooths. However, in the high country conditions are such that sheep are slower maturing, and they are usually not bred from for another year. These unmated two tooths are referred to as `maiden' ewes. <i>(1949,High Country Days,195</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> <i>Maiden Ewe</i>: Normally ewes are first bred from as two-tooths. However, in the high country, conditions are such that sheep are slower maturing, and they are smetimes not bred from for another year. These unmated two-tooths are referred to as `maiden ewes'. <i>(1966,Boss's Story, The,188</i>)



 
 <i>adj.</i> applied to country; or on West Coast to a beach with gold-bearing BLACK-SAND deposits not yet worked

>  <b>PFAFF</b> We went up the creek to prospect ... We pushed on into maiden country, i.e. the Right Hand Branch, and got very good prospects. <i>(1914,Diggers' Story, The,43</i>)

## maihi
 
 <i>n.</i> carved facing-boards on the gable of a Maori building. [Maori maihi[a-macron]]

>  <b>POLACK</b> We passed an extensive grove containing a Wai-tapu [a2-acute]. In this place was deposited the bones of a male and female chief ... The house which enclosed these remains of mortality was built of old canoes, ... [138] It was surmounted with a <i>maihi</i>, or frontispiece, which was decorated with feathers. <i>(1838,New Zealand  (Polack),1/137</i>)

>  <b>POLACK</b> Round the top a head-board (<i>maihi</i>) was affixed, on which a number of obscene figures were carved. <i>Ibid.</i> 1/206 Over the door-ways and window-sills, handsomely carved boards are fixed, painted in flaming red, these are placed horizontally or in a gable form called <i>maihi</i>, surmounted by a wooden image termed the <ik>taupare</i> [a2-acute] <i>warre</i> [e-acute]; some of these figures are exceedingly droll. ... [Caption] The Maihi, a carved board for the front of a house, surmounted by the Toupare [e-acute], or figure-head. <i>(1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/123</i>)

>  The ridge-boards are carved to represent a number of<i> ngarara</i>, or lizards, running along the roof, and the <i>maihi</i>, or gable-boards, have carvings of the mythological animal known as the <i>manaia</i> - probably a kind of taniwha. <i>(1895,TrNZI,27/674</i>)

>  <b>TREGEAR</b> In front of the verandah of a house, short perpendicular slabs (<i>amo</i>), often carved or painted, supported the barge-boards (<i>maihi</i>) of the gable, and formed very striking and highly embellished adornments. <i>(1904,Maori Race, The,273</i>)

>  The carvings (all but the maihi) were finished by the Rotorua school some months ago ... <i>(1933,Letter</i>) [NOTES: Ngata; 1933 June 11 in 1988 Na To Hoa Aroha (Ngata-Buck Correspondence) 3/88]

>  <i>Maihi,</i> facing-boards joining a gable of Maori house, ornamented with incised carving, deeply incised at lower ends, even perforated: the koruru covers the join at gable, a grotesque figure surmounting the koruru: the upright supports at lower ends are amo. <i>(Jun 1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/153</i>) [NOTES: (J.C.Andersen)]

>  <b>BUCK</b> The barge-boards (<i>maihi) were wide planks which were dubbed out with a longitudinal flange (<i>papawai</i>) on the back near the lowere edge. <i>(1949,Coming of the Maori, The,129</i>)

>  <i>(May 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,502/2</i>) [NOTES: [OEDS]]

>  <b>MASON</b> Although the house lacks a central gable, there is a smaller one above the window, left. Some attempt has been made to turn this into a maihi - the carved boards of a Maori gable. <i>(1969,Awatea,15,1978 ed.</i>)

>  The ever-reaching strong hand of death is another image commonly spoken about at Maori gatherings today, but it is not clear whether the stylized hand portrayed on meeting house maihi (bargeboards), or on ko (spades), or on some very old examples of taonga have the same korero attached to them. <i>(1984,Te Maori,27</i>)

>  There is St Mary's, one of the most richly decorated Maori churches in New Zealand; the red maihi of a wharenui across the road. <i>(Jul 12, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),61</i>)

>  <b>PHILLIPPS</b> The carved lower portion of the <i>maihi</i>, or bargeboard... is termed <i>raparapa</i>. <i>(1950,Maori Carving,6</i>) [NOTES: 2nd edition]

>  <b>PHILLIPPS</b> From this we may conclude that the maihi were cut and prepared in a timber-factory in Whanganui on order from the builders. <i>Ibid.</i> 135. On the other side we find a human figure near the lower maihi end... Spirals are absent, and borders of whakarare adorn the maihi. <i>(1955,Carved Maori Houses,107</i>)

>  <b>MEAD</b> Besides the very ornate maihi, amo and pae (threshold) it was not unusual for the complete front wall to be a mass of carvings.<i>Ibid.</i> 51 The maihi is plain throughout its length. <i>(1961,Art of Maori Carving, The,12</i>)

>  <b>BARROW</b> [Caption] A vertical panel, one of a pair supporting the left bargeboard (maihi) of the Arawa storehouse named Puwai-o-to-Arawa. <i>(1969,Maori Wood Sculpture,116</i>)

>  In the 1880's the amo and maihi passed into the hands of Archdeacon Henry Williams who in 1913 presented them to the Dominion Museum. <i>(May 2005,Kokiri Paetae,11</i>)

## maimai
 
 <i>n.</i> a duckshooter's shelter or hiding place usually made of (manuka) brushwood [1845. R. Howitt, `Australia,' p. 103: -->1. (obs) a rough temporary bush shelter quickly put together from branches, etc. (Perhaps originally thought to refer to Maori shelters, thence in early colonial use, thence by trampers and mountaineers); a bush hut]

>  <b>GUNBY</b> Rolls and rolls of crepe paper would be draped to provide a room that looked like a series of "mai-mais" around the periphery of the hall. <i>(1984,Rangiora High School 1884-1984,185</i>)

>  <b>BUTLER</b> The few Maories that inhabit this settlement travel to the west coast by way of this river. They always go on foot, and we saw several traces of their encampments - little <i>mimis,</i> as they are called - a few light sticks thrown together, and covered with grass, affording a sort of half-and-half shelter for a single individual. <i>(1863,First Year in Canterbury Settlement,v/72</i>)

>  <b>WRIGHT</b> They were big rough sheep on the Maimai, fit to make a shearer's heart / Settle down about his boot-tops on the morning of the start. <i>Ibid.</i> 37 But he wouldn't shear at Maimai. <i>(1897,Station Ballads,35</i>)

>  The weather was appalling and every time we lifted our heads above the brush parapet of the maimai we were met with blasting sleet and salt water which stung the eyes and numbed cheeks and any other exposed extremities. <i>(Aug 9, 2003,Dominion Post,F8</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> Perhaps it was this [sc. the Ring of God's blessing] which kept the old maimai church intact for such a long time. <i>(1979,Titi Heritage,98</i>) [NOTES: NB- The term mai-mai is used in Wilson for the makeshift huts on the mutton-bird islands - does it deserve a separate entry from shooting mai-mais in which case I may have to get a further cit.?]

>  Chew into a bit of possum, muttonbird, thar, goat, eel and kangaroo during the Monteith's Wild Food Challenge which started yesterday... It's all in aid of celebrating our pioneer roots, and a lot easier than going bush with a couple of dogs and a knife or sitting in a freezing maimai hoping for unwitting feathered shot-gun fodder. <i>(Jun 1, 2002,Evening Post,2</i>)

>  An instance of the use of such a `mai-mai' [a frame-work lean-to made with saplings; with ferns laced in-and-out for a roof, while the ends are blocked with scrub or fern. `We then stretch a fly over this (or perhaps under) allowing it to overlap some four feet in front, to cover the fire"] was seen at the snout of the Fox Glacier. <i>(May 1895,NZ Alpine Journal,2/7/24</i>) [NOTES: The ref is obscure. This is a guess at its placve of publication but there wouldn't have been an Alp[ine Journal then. Possibly from Harper 1896 Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ]

>  <b>MOFFAT</b> [I] stripped some bark off a cedar or totara tree [in Nelson], I am not sure which, built a maimai big enough to crawl into, managed to get a fire, caught and roasted a woodhen, boiled some flour in my pannikin, ... [c 1860]. <i>(1896,Adventures by Sea and Land,61,1979 ed.</i>)

>  <b>HARPER</b> ... it is really not necessary to carry canvas [on the West Coast] unless ... one is fastidious as to shelter. It is always possible to build a good `whare'[e-acute] or `mai-mai' with bark stripped from the rata (<i>Metrosideros robusta</i>), totara ..., or cedar (<i>Libocedrus Bidwillii</i>) trees ... <i>(1896,Pioneer Work in the Alps of NZ,35</i>)

>  <b>MORRIS</b> <i>Mia-mia, n</i>. an aboriginal hut. The word is aboriginal, and has been spelt variously. <i>Mia-mia</i> is the most approved spelling, <i>mi-mi</i> the most approved pronunciation. See <i>Humpy.</i> <i>(1898,Austral English,291</i>)

>  <b>VAILE</b> <i>Mai-mai</i> a covert <i>(1939,Pioneering the Pumice,299</i>)

>  <b>BEATTIE</b> Another term brought over from Australia [from the 1860's on] was "maimai' for a rough shelter from the weather. It was said to be a name for a black-fellow's camp, which I have always seen spelt `miamia', and which is called `gunyah' or `wurley', etc. by some tribes. We now apply the name to shooting shelters. <i>(1947,Early Runholding in Otago,10</i>)

>  <b>SLATTER</b> Bert looking out the porthole at the wide Pacific and saying not a duck to be seen, what a helluva mai-mai this is. <i>(1959,Gun in My Hand, A,224</i>)

>  <b>McCALLUM</b> It gets plenty cold in the mai mai early in the morning [duckshooting] <i>Ibid.</i> 98<i>Maimai</i> Duck shooter's place of concealment. <i>(1963,Half-Gallon Jar,39</i>)

>  <b>BAXTER</b> ... More than a shroud/ He needs the maimai's breast of shade,/ ... when loud/ On ragged flights the shotguns played - <i>(1979,Collected Poems,304</i>) [NOTES: 1961-64) 1979 Baxter Collected Poems 304]

>  <b>McLEOD</b> <i>Mimi</i>: Corruption of Maori word for a hide or shelter. [sic] <i>(1972,Mountain World,310</i>)

>  <b>BAXTER</b> (note)<i> maimai</i> word of Maori derivation by which New Zealand duck-shooters refer to the shelter of green branches constructed by the hunters for camouflage. <i>(1979,Collected Poems,632</i>)

>  <b>LELAND</b> ~ There you are, crouching, cold, wet(?), and expectant in your little hut among the reeds next to your favorite lake. Duck season is about to open and you await the sunrise and the game in your DUCK BLIND. <i>(1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,61</i>)

>  <b>BAXTER</b> <i>maimai</i> hide used by duckshooters <i>(1982,Selected Poems,188</i>)

>  <i>mai mai n. N.Z.</i> a duck-shooter's shelter; hide. [< Maori] [sic] <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,680</i>) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 452; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 296]]

When I was a boy I heard sheep called `jumbucks,' an Australian aborigine term for them, but with the decease of ex-Australian stockmen the word has gone out of use now. ## mainland island
 
 <i>n.</i> (Environment) an area of mainland (as opposed to offshore) vegetation where predatory mammals, such as rats and possums, are controlled or removed to allow native animals and plants to survive; an onshore sanctuary for indigenous plant and animal species

>  Near the top of the spur that leads to the tops, I pass a deer-exclusion fence around a monitoring site, one component of the recovery project, set up using techniques developed on Kapiti Island with a view to developing an 825-hectare, pest-free "mainland island". <i>(Jun 12, 2004,Dominion Post,E16</i>)

>  It is all part of a mission to create a mainland island in the 1250-hectare (3125-acre) East Harbour Regional Park... Thanks to Mr Hunt and 20 other members of his Mainland Island Recovery Operation the dawn chorus is being heard more frequently around Eastbourne. <i>(Apr 22, 2004,Dominion Post,A7</i>)

>  This is a "mainland island", where DOC is trying to put back what's been lost: namely the native birds, reptiles, insects and plants driven to local extinction by introduced pests. <i>(Dec 28, 2005,Dominion Post,C2</i>)

>  The term mainland island derives from the conservation work done on many offshore islands in the 1970s, 80s and 90s. <i>(Jul 2007,NZ Geographic,86/82</i>)

>  The whio result was reported last month at a meeting near Mangaweka of DOC staff working on intensive pest control at sites known as "mainland islands" and volunteers from private mainland island-type projects around New Zealand... Unlike real islands or the fenced-off Karori Wildlife Sanctuary, mainland islands are open to invasion or re-invasion by animal pests which must be kept at low numbers for targeted native species to thrive. <i>(Aug 20, 2003,Dominion Post,B5</i>)

>  He says DOC is doing a good job in its intensively managed islands and so-called "mainland island" reserves (areas of parks and reserves that are rigorously policed for pests and other threats to the native wildlife). <i>(Jul 31, 2004,Dominion Post,E2</i>)

>  MAINLAND ISLANDS - TEN YEARS ON [hdg]Thanks to mainland islands, major improvements have been made in the way conservation work is done. <i>(Jun 2007,Conservation Action,42</i>)

## mairoero
 
 <i>n.</i> (See [(cf MIROROI)](../(#(cf-miroroi)))

>  <b>MONRO</b> Behind Toutuki, [the prospective Otago settler] may explore the mountain dreaded by the natives, on account of its being the favourite residence of the mairoero. This is a wild man of the woods, strong, cunning, and mischievous, and addicted to running off with young people and damsels. His body is covered with coarse and long hair, which also flows down from the back of his head nearly to his heels. To com-[263]pensate for this excessive quantity behind, his forehead is said to be bald. He was vividly described to us by a Maori who had seen one long ago, when he was a little boy, and was of opinion that `there is not a more fearful wild-fowl that your <i>mairoero</i> living.' <i>(1844,Notes of a Journey,262</i>) [NOTES: 1844 Monro Notes of a Journey (Nelson Examiner July 20 et seq.) in 1898 Hocken Contributions 262-263]

## make

 <i>v.</i> (Rural) [sheep] to move of its own accord

 <i>v.</i> of a sheep dog

## make a rise
 
 <i>phr.</i> make a sum, make a profit

I made a rise in Queensland once, at the Towers, but it all went soon; and now I have given New Zealand a turn ...; and have had the good fortune to drop on you. <i>(1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,30</i>)

>  <b>PFAFF</b> I bought and sold flour ..., got a 3-1/2 oz. nugget from the bottom of a hole that had been left, made a rise of [pounds]300 out of a pocket of gold like horse beans. <i>(1914,Diggers' Story, The,115</i>)

>  <b>VEITCH</b> By mid-June [1864] disappointed miners were returning from Picton to try once again to `make a rise' from the banks of the Clutha where it was possible to realise at least a couple of pennyweights a day using only the humble cradle. <i>(1976,Clyde on the Dunstan,30</i>)

 <i>phr.</i> to make a smoke signal [ca1952 Dec Hollyford Valley, Davie Gunn (advising tyro trampers) HWO `Make a smoke for the steamer at Greenstone [on Lake Wakatipu].'] (See [also put up (a) smoke](../A#also-put-up-(a)-smoke))

## makomako
 
 <i>n.</i> <i>Anthornis melanura</i>, bellbird, korimako, mocker [cons var here] (See [see bellbird. b) see wineberry](../S#see-bellbird.-b)-see-wineberry))

>  <b>KIRK</b> The wood of the manaoa is of a light-brown colour. <i>(1889,Forest Flora,192</i>)

>  <b>HOOKER</b> Manaoa, Dacrydium Colensoi. <i>(1867,Handbook NZ Flora,II 766</i>)

>  The open pumice land is covered with a tangled mass of manuka and manaoa, with tussock on the colder flats. In developing pumice country a great saving can be effected in clearing costs if the manuka and manaoa scrub are burnt standing two or three years ahead of cultivation. Dense manaoa scrub is difficult and costly to clear in its green state, but it carries a fire well and its burnt stubs soon rot. <i>(Jul 16, 1945,NZ Journal of Agriculture,17</i>)

## manawa
 
 <i>n.</i> a small native mangrove tree, Avicennia marina, of tidal mudflats of the northern North Island. [ORIGIN: Maori] (See [mangrove](../M#mangrove))

>  <b>POLACK</b> <i>Manawa and Tuputupu,</i> two varieties of the well-known mangrove, cover the mud banks of the rivers and creeks of the country in which they flourish. <i>(1838,New Zealand  (Polack),2/398</i>)

>  <b>DIEFFENBACH</b> The arms of the Parenga-renga inlet ... generally terminate in swamps, grown over with what is called the New Zealand mangrove (Avicennia tomentosa), named manawa by the natives. <i>(1843,Travels in NZ,1/204</i>)

>  <b>HOOKER</b> Avicennia <i>tomentosa</i>, L. ... Nat. name, `Manawa', <i>Cunn. </i> <i>(1853,Flora NZ,I Flowering Plants 204</i>)

>  <b>HOOKER</b> Maanawa, <i>Col[enso]. Avicennia tomentosa. </i> <i>(1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),766</i>)

>  <b>TAYLOR</b> The Manawa (<i>Mangrove</i>) is very abundant, and prized for the soap manufactory, from the great quantity of potash it contains. <i>(1868,Past and Present of NZ,205</i>)

>  b. <i>for tanning</i>; the Toatoa, or Tanekaha ..., the Makamaka (<i>Ackama rosaefolia</i>), so closely allied to the Towai; the Manaawa, or White Mangrove (<i>Avicennia tomentosa</i>,) ... <i>(1869,TrNZI,1/III/50</i>) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

>  <b>HAY</b> The Manawa, or `mangrove' (<i>Avicennia officinalis</i>), is very plentiful in the north, ... <i>(1882,Brighter Britain,2/197</i>)

>  [Native name] Manawa .. [Settlers' name] Mangrove .. [Family] Verbenaceae <i>(1902,Settler's Handbook of NZ, The,122</i>) [NOTES: 1886 T.Kirk in 1902 Settler's Handbook of NZ 122]

>  <b>CHEESEMAN</b> <i>[Avicennia officinalis, Linn.]</i> NORTH ISLAND: Muddy creeks and estuaries from North Cape to Opotiki and Kawhia on the west. <i>Manawa; Mangrove. </i> <i>(1906,Manual NZ Flora,567</i>)

>  <b>LAING & BLACKWELL</b> <i>Avicennia officinalis (The Mangrove)</i> ... Maori name, <i>Manawa. </i> <i>(1907,Plants of NZ,352,1940 p. 373 ed.</i>)

>  <b>55/153</b> <i>ma[a]nawa</i>, an amphibolic tree (Avicennia officinalis), mangrove. Without the macron, manawa, the meaning is bowels, heart, breath, patience, mind, spirit: in the place-name Manawatu, heart startled and standing still for a momentl or, heart at rest and peace. <i>(1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society</i>) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

>  <b>59/1</b> <i>(Nov 1957,NZ Timber Journal</i>)

 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a New Zealand-bred cultivar of ryegrass, Lolium multiflorum. [ORIGIN: Maori]

>  Ryegrass cultivars differ markedly in susceptibility. Ruanui and Ariki are often more severely infected [with blind seed disease] than Manawa and Paroa, probably because the latter two cultivars flower later. <i>(Oct 1974,NZ Journal of Agriculture,19</i>)

 <i>n.</i> <i>Lygodium articulatum,</i>a climbing fern. [ORIGIN: Maori, various spellings]

>  <b>TRACEY</b> ... with a mungi-mungi vine for our line ... . <i>(1925,Piriki's Princess,88</i>)

>  <b>JOHNSON</b> There is scarcely a bare stem to be seen, even the tallest are embraced by a variety of twining plants, parasites and creepers, amongst which the <i>kia-kia</i>, decked at every joint with bunches of iris-shaped leaves, and the <i>mangamanga,</i> a creeping fern, are the most conspicuous; the <i>kareo</i>, also, forming a network of cane-like stems, hangs its bunches of glossy leaves pendant from every bough, and many others of equal beauty join to form a verdant arch, midway between the spreading branches of the noble trees to which they cling. <i>(1847,Notes of a Journey</i>) [NOTES: 1847 Johnson Notes from a Journal in 1959 Taylor Early Travellers 121]

>  <b>HOOKER</b> A remarkable genus of climbing Ferns, with slender wiry stems, found in all tropical countries. ... Lygodium <i>articulatum</i>, A Rich. ... Nat. name, `Mange-mange', <i>Col. </i> <i>(1855,Flora NZ,II Flowerless Plants 47</i>)

>  Mattresses in the bunks made from dried mangi-mangi ... [pron. mungi- mungi] creeper found in the bush in Northland. <i>(1951,Radio NZ / National Radio</i>) [NOTES: [c1914] 1951 H.S. McCarroll The Days of the Kauri Bushmen [Radio Talk 1: TS]]

>  <b>KEENE</b> <i>mangemange</i>: a climbing fern. <i>(1963,O Te Raki,192</i>)

>  <b>MOORE & IRWIN</b> <i>LYGODIUM ARTICULATUM</i> (Schizaeceae). The strangest thins about mangemange is that the true stem is very short but the leaf goes on growing at its tip and may be many metres long. In kauri forest these tough wiry leaves wind round trees and shrubs in an impenetrable network. On the shores are oysters, mussels, cockles, mutton-fish, crabs, and other shell-fish in profuse abundance. In the fresh-water creeks are eels (tuna), lampreys (pipiharau), and whitebait (inanga). <i>(1882,Brighter Britain,2/151</i>)

## Manpower Act
 
 <i>n.</i> [There seems to be no Manpower Act or Manpower Regulations as such. What we had instead were various amendments to the National Service Emergency Regulations promulgated first in 1940, when they referred mainly to the Services and spoke of Placement Officers and which I suspect were the "Manpower Regulations" of the time. The first relevant regulation seems to be 1942 Statutory Regulations 5/19 The National Service Emergency Regulations 1940, Amendment No. 8: There shall from time to time be appointed.. such number of District Man-power Officers as may be required. Ibid. 21. In any essential undertaking.. (a) Except with the permission in writing of the District Man-power Officer, the employer shall not terminate.. the employment of any person for the time being employed therein.. except in case of emergency... (b) Except with the permission in writing of the District Man-power Officer, no person for the time being employed in the undertaking shall leave his employment... Ibid. 24. The Minister may.. direct all persons of any specified class or of specified classes.. to register for employment with the District Man-power Office.]

## manu

A southern Maori once said to me:- `We did not pronounce the word manuka like some northerners who throw the accent forward and say `man-u-ka,' nor like the bushmen, who say `m'nooka,' but about halfway between these two pronouncing each part clearly as mah-nook-a.' Unless my hearing deceives me this throws the emphasis on the central syllable while leaving the first syllable clearly pronounced. >  <i>ma[a]nuka</i>, a shrub (Leptospermum scoparium), commonly called tea-tree, because Cook's people used the fresh young leaves infused for tea; but very often mis-spelt ti-tree - ti being something totally different, the cabbage tree (Cordyline). The tree-manuka is kanuka, with smaller leaves and smaller flowers than the scrub-manuka, and it is the kanuka that is usually sold for firewood. I spoke to a dealer about it, and he said they dodged the confusion by selling it as T.T. There is a crimson-flowering variety of manuka known in England as a rarity, but by means of slips (not seed) it has become not uncommon. The starry-flowered manuka would have been adopted as the national flower but for the fact that it is too prolific, and apt to become a nuisance. It has a second name, kahika[a]toa but that is discouraged on account of its spelling being so nearly the same as kahikatea, the white pine, though in sound they are quite different, the macron in hahika[a]toa causing an apparent accent which, when observed, clearly differentiates the two words: it is not an accent, however, but a lengthening of the vowel. <i>(1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/144</i>) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

## manuka blight
 
 <i>n.</i> a black blight which kills manuka scrub

>  <i>(Apr 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,337/1</i>)

>  MANUKA BLIGHT [heading] Since first noted in the Canterbury district in 1937, the scale insect <i>Eriococcus scoparium</i>, has ... become widely established. <i>(Oct 1959,Tararua Tramper,7</i>)

>  The manuka blight was first introduced into the [Hawkes Bay] region in 1945 ... [fn] The blight is caused by the action of a small sucking insect which feeds on the sap of the manuka and which secretes large quantities of a clear sticky substance known as `honey-dew'. A black sooty mould forms on this secretion. A combination of sap loss and mould slowly kills the plant. <i>(Oct 1954,NZ Geographer,110</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> Manuka on Stewart Island is sometimes blackened but seldom killed by manuka blight. <i>(1982,Stewart Island Plants,52 ed.</i>)

>  The deliberate spread of manuka blight, growing in popularity in some areas, is not favoured by departmental officers. <i>(Apr 4, 1950,Southern Cross (Wgton),10</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a sooty mould formed on honey-dew exuded by a scale insect infesting red manuka and kanuka.

## Maori
 
 <i>n.</i> (attrib. use) Maori(dom) as a field of study

 <i>n.</i> [There is a discussion on the word in the `Journal of Polynesian Society,' vol. i. no. 3, vol. ii. no. I, and vol. iii. no. I. Bishop Williams (4th ed.) says that the word means, `of the normal or usual kind.' The Pakehas were not men to whom the natives were accustomed. So Maori was used as opposed to the Europeans, the white-skins. <i>Kuri Maori</i> was a name used for a dog after the arrival of other quadrupeds called also <i>kuri. Wai maori</i> was fresh-water, oridinary as opposed to sea-water. Another explanation is that the word meant `indigenous,' and that there are kindred words with that meaning in other Polynesian languages. First, `indigenous,' or "of the native race,' and then with a secondary meaning, `ours.' (See `Tregear's Maori Comparative Dictionary,' s.v.) The form of the plural varies, The form <i>Maoris</i> is considered the more correct, but the form <i>Maories</i> is frequently used by good writers.]

>  <b>DUFF</b> This raises the question of what we mean by the term Maori. Why should Kupe be termed a Maori, if (according to Maori tradition) he was a Society Islands voyager of some 1,000 years ago who touched at New Zealand in the course of exploring voyages and returned to his homeland? By what greater right can we apply the term to Toi who arrived from the same part of the Pacific 200 years later to settle in New Zealand, or to the numerous voyagers subsequent to Toi and culminating in the Hawaiki Fleet of 1350? Every immigrant from tropical Polynesia did not become a Maori the moment he stepped ashore in New Zealand. The culture which we have come to know as Maori was undoubtedly the end product of a long period of local development, probably not reaching its final perfection of form until after the visit of Tasman. The use of the term Maori (lit. normal, ordinary or proper) to distinguish the Polynesian inhabitants of New Zealand from the intrusive European is even more clearly a late development and certainly post-European.* [fn] Williams (1921) notes no literary use before 1850 of the Maori in its present sense. Scholefield (1945) puts its use back to 1840, in the translation of the Treaty of Waitangi. McNab, quoted by Shrimpton and Mulgan, without the reference being cited, states that its earliest use was in 1818. <i>(1977,Moa-Hunters of NZ,12</i>)

 <i>n.</i> an aboriginal or native New Zealander; pertaining to the Maori. Spg <i>Mouri, Mauri, Mawnee</i>, [? typographical or transcription error], in the earliest texts; <i>mouray Mao[diereis]ri Maori</i> from at least 1842 (with occasional lower case m.) Plural. Mauries, Mauris, Mouries, Maories; Mauri, Mouri, Maori. The plural <i>Maories</i> can be found in written texts to the 1870's or 1880's; and is not uncommon in informal written English today, though usually regarded as a spelling error. The plural <i>Maori</i> has been usual among those with knowledge of Maori; and among those who are sensitive to Maori usage or feeling. <i>Synonyms.</i> Leaving aside the very early (Cook, Banks) <i>Indian </i>q.v., early writers used <i>native</i> (as n and aj.) or <i>New Zealander </i>q.v. as the preferred terms, with<i> aborigine</i> q.v. being common in early writing asociated with `imperial' agencies as the Colonial Office and the Church Missionary Society, and was reinforced by the early appointment of a <i>Protector of Aborigines</i>. Early uses of <i>Maori</i> were usually tagged with an explanatory `native"; and indeed <i>Maori </i>did not replace <i>Native</i> in official use until 1947 when the name of the Department of Native Affairs was replaced by `Maori Affairs'.

>  <b>MORRIS</b> <i>Maori, n.</i> (pronounced so as to rhyme with <i>Dowry</i>). (I) The name used to designate themselves by the Polynesian race occupying New Zealand when it was discovered by the white man, and which still survives. They are not aboriginal as is commonly supposed, but migrated into New Zealand about 500 years ago from Hawaii, the tradition still surviving of the two great canoes <i>Arawa</i> and <i>Tainui</i> in which the pioneers arrived. They are commonly spoken of as the <i>Natives</i> of New Zealand. -->(2) The language of the Maori race. -->(3) Applied to anything pertaining to the Maoris or their language. See Pakeha. -->There is a discussion on the word in the `Journal of Polynesian Society,' vol. i. no. 3, vol. ii. no. I, and vol. iii. no. I. Bishop Williams (4th ed.) says that the word means, `of the normal or usual kind.' The Pakehas were not men to whom the natives were accustomed. So Maori was used as opposed to the Europeans, the white-skins. <i>Kuri Maori</i> was a name used for a dog after the arrival of other quadrupeds called also <i>kuri. Wai maori</i>was fresh-water, ordinary as opposed to sea-water. Another explanation is that the word meant `indigenous,' and that there are kindred words with that meaning in other Polynesian languages. First, `indigenous,' or "of the native race,' and then with a secondary meaning, `ours.' (See `Tregear's Maori Comparative Dictionary,' s.v.) The form of the plural varies, The form <i>Maoris</i> is considered the more correct, but the form <i>Maories</i> is frequently used by good writers. <i>(1898,Austral English,284</i>)

 <i>n.</i> plural is Maoris or Maori 1. a) a member of the tangata whenua, the Polynesian race that first peopled New Zealand. b) a Polynesian of the Cook Islands. Compare PAKEHA. 2. their languages. Maori adjective (usually capital, can be offensive in some non-Maori use) 1. a) of or pertaining to Maori peoples or culture (often replacing earlier native): `Maori Battalion'; `Maori Affairs Department'; `Maori oven'. b) use can be derogatory or stereotypical: `Maori cannon'. 2. a) indigenous, native to New Zealand: `Maori bug'; `Maori hen'. b) undomesticated (synonym is wild): `Maori cabbage'; `Maori celery'; `Maori dog'. [Maori Maori originally an adjective, normal, usual, ordinary] [For fuller discussion of theories of origin, and applications, of MAORI (and PAKEHA) see Journal Polynesian Soc. 54/4/223-234; [etc.] Maori, <i>maaori </i> see also taha maori, tangata maori, copper maori , pro-Maori include in article Maori as a subject of study: e.g. Maori was admitted at last as a university subject: a Chair of Maori ??? -->pl forms Maori the native race, or several Maoris, is becoming the preferred pl among maoriphiles: Maories quite common until the 1870s;]

<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> the Maori language, the only use of Maori in the early journals: cf [ed fn] This is one of the rare occasions in which the word `Maori', as meaning a `person of the native race', is used by the missionaries. But its use here as meaning `the language of the native race' would seem to indicate that it was not an unusual name, although the missionaries and others normally used `native' or `New Zealander'. ## Maori ear
 
 <i>n.</i> an ear infection, allegedly prevalent among Maori children; ? glue ear

>  A special report on the subject which the medical statistics branch of the Health Department has issued makes this point [of the prevalence of ear, nose, and throat disease among Maoris]. For more than half a century the `Maori ear' had been regarded in medical practice as a most unrewarding condition to treat in more ways than one and by both parties concerned, the report said. If future generations of Maori children retained their greater susceptibility to ear disease, every year would add to the size of the problem till it might become too big ever to be solved. <i>(Sep 2, 1965,Dominion,2</i>)



## Maori English
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>LAWLOR</b> [Dick Harris in Introduction] The reader should be warned that the apparently phonetic spelling of English as it is commonly supposed to be spoken by Hori is not to be accepted as authentic `Maori English'. <i>(1926,Maori Tales,9</i>)

>  It is sometimes stated that a Maori child's spoken vocabulary often lacks idiom. It is true that he has limited access to the wide range of expressions that enrich the English language, but `Maori English' is perhaps excessively idiomatic in its use of colloquial phrases, slang, and short, pithy expressions that convey more meaning than is in bare words. The range is not wide , however, and the expressions are used repetively, often to reinforce a meaning rather than add to it. <i>(1971,Maori Children & the Teacher,42</i>)

>  `Restricted Codes and Maori English' [title] A recent (1971) N.Z. Department of Education publication, Maori Children and the Teacher (henceforth MCT), discusses at some length the question of `Maori English' and the language of Maori children. [<i>Ibid </i>68] I hope to have shown, in this review, that we should not accept uncritically the assumption that Maori English constitutes a restricted code or that Maori children are cognitively deficient. We know that Maori English is different from Standard English and we are aware of some of the factors that make it so. ... evidence and ... <i>(May 1972,NZ Journal Educ. Studies,59 ed.</i>) [NOTES: P.Hawkins]

## Maori land
 
 <i>n.</i> land held under customary title or as Maori freehold land [Jim Cameron writes: The legal definition of Maori land in DNZE is confusing. <i>Maori customary land</i> is land held in accordance with tikanga Maori. <i>Maori freehold land</i> is essentially (there are minor qualifications) land that has been converted to English freehold tenure and has not been alienated to non-Maori. There are several trusts for various forms of Maori landholding - <i>ahi whenua trusts, kitiakai trusts, putea trusts, whanau trusts</i> and <i>whenua topu trusts</i>. Note also <i> status orders</i>. See Te Ture Whenua Maori Act 1993.]

THOMSON</b> By chance in 1984 I received a boole from the International Potato Center at Lima, Peru ... and the cover shows Andean potato cultivars - some very similar to the `Urenika' type. >  The Maori Potato The ancient potato cultivars commonly referred to as Maori potatoes may be descended from tubers given to the Maori by early explorers, or they may have come direct from South America with the early colonisation of the Pacific. Doug Yen ... now at the Bishop Museum appears to have been the first to collect and study these early potatoes (<i>The Potato Journal summer 1961/61:</i> 2-5) and he refers to the introductions by de Surville in 1769 and 1772 and by Cook in 1773. Yen also refers to the possible introduction direct from South America, since Callao in Peru and Acapulco in Mexico were provisioning ports for whaling vessels. This year I grew `Urenaka' (Yen refers to `Urenika') ... and I understand this cultivar came from the East Coast. It is certainly an unusual potato with purplish stems and tubers. ... Yen ... notes that they resemble the storied (Iodine) potato of Ireland, used as a talisman against illness. ... Audrey [Eagle] said that when she gave some [similar] tubers to a Maori lady she exclaimed `ah, rokekuri'. <i>(1983,Botany Division (DSIR) Newsletter,No. 85/11</i>) [NOTES: (A.D. Thomson)]

## Maori sickness
 
 <i>n.</i> (See [mate Maori](../M#mate-maori))

>  <b>BEAGLEHOLE</b> .. he thinks of sickness, particularly that kind of sickness which he calls Maori sickness, as very often caused by spirits as a punishment for the violation of tapu or custom. <i>Ibid.</i> 219 The sign most often taken to indicate this sort of sickness is that the sickness does not appear to be yielding readily to ordinary Maori or to pakeha methods of treatment. It is then considered to be a Maori sickness - a `mate Maori' as the phrase is commonly used - and for sure, safe, and quick results, treatment should be referred to a Maori expert, a tohunga, either male or female, who will use a combination of religious prayer, seance-possession, and magic to restore the sick person to health. ## Maori time
 
 <i>n.</i> a relaxed and flexible view of time as a regulator of people's activities, reputedly a Maori characteristic (compare Pakeha time).

>  The phrase "Maori time" has not been abroad much of late, but recent events have highlighted a linguistic gap that it will fill very neatly. Maori time is a period of 12 days, or the length of time that elapses between a major disaster and the government's getting around to doing something about it when that disaster affects a predominantly Maori community, say, in the Far North. <i>(Feb 20, 1999,Listener (New Zealand Listener),61</i>)

>  <b>McGill</b> "Kia ora," said Rangi Rangihau, grinning. "...Sorry we're late, my friends. You know how it is. Maori time, eh?" <i>(1995,Gold in the Creek,36</i>)

## Maori village settlement
 
 <i>n.</i> [scheme to establish villages espressly for Maori]

## Maori Warden
 
 <i>n.</i> a semi-official, uniformed volunteer who patrols public places, bars, etc., in ways helpful to Maori people and others.

>  <b>HUTT</b> Maori Wardens were appointed in 1949 as a result of the Liquor Licensing Bill 1948. Wardens were administered through the Department of Maori Affairs and nominated by tribal executives. Wardens had power over liquor and liqor-related disturbances within tribal districts, with powers over Maori pub patrons and over Pakeha at hui or if there was sly-grogging... In many ways the Maori wardens were following in the tradition of the Ringatu pirihimana, the Ratana katipa and the Kingite watene. <i>(1999,Maori & Alcohol,73</i>) [NOTES: See FLERAS <i>A Descriptive Analysis of Maori Wardens in the Historical and Contemporary Context of New Zealand Society</i>", Ph.D, VUW, 1980, esp. pp.269-275]

## Maori wedding
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>OWEN & PERKINS</b> In those days [c1890s] they had what was known as the `Maori wedding', which was not legal to the Pakeha, but was a binding thing among the Maori people themselves. A young couple would decide that they wanted to become man and wife, and they would have to tell their parents they wanted this. ## Maoritanga
 
 <i>n.</i> a general name for traditions, practices and beliefs which are Maori, as distinct from Pakeha. [ORIGIN: Maori]

>  <b>DIEFFENBACH</b> Maoritanga - native custom, natural use <i>(1843,Travels in NZ,2/370</i>)

>  There is no doubt that more than the spirit which pervades our people on development work ..., what impressed the Tokerau delegates last year when they visited those districts was the `maoritanga' of the tribes inhabiting that part of the Eastern Maori electorate. It was not a maoritanga of the lips as among the Waikato, but was manifested in persistent cultural traits, carvings, plaiting, marae ceremonial, poetry and song, speech and so forth. <i>(Jun 11, 1933,Richmond-Atkinson Papers,3/85</i>) [NOTES: (Ngata)]

>  <b>ZIMMERMAN</b> Immediately she came in, however, something within her made her incline to the <i>maoritanga</i> of her companions, and I believe it was at her request that the girls began to speak only Maori in their free hours and at meals, ... <i>(1946,Where the People Sing,59</i>)

>  <b>CRUISE</b> Only less [9] astonishing than the number of chiefs who went overseas, even to England, during this time was the contrast between their general bearing while away and the resumption of their Maoritanga on their return. <i>(1957,Journal</i>) [NOTES: 1957 Bagnall Introduction to 1823 Cruise Journal (1957) 8-9]

>  <i>maoritanga n -s usu cap</i> [Maori] 1 : the traditions and ideals and culture of the Maori people 2 : Maori nationalism <i>(1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1379</i>)

>  <b>CAMERON</b> To a certain extent, in fact, <i>Maoritanga</i> is not a matter of inheritance; it is a matter of <i>he manawa</i>, of `how one feels.' <i>Ibid.</i> 75 But when Sir James Carroll and other leaders of the Young Maori Party wanted a term to denote the way of life of their people, they took the completely-assimilated modern meaning of the word `Maori' - which, thanks to the <i>pakeha</i>, transcended tribal boundaries - and coined a new meaning for `Maoritanga.' The meaning of the term is debated and discussed, analyzed and defined, used and abused with great frequency in the present upsurge of interest in Maori culture and traditional ways of thinking, feeling, and acting. A second Maori renaissance seems to be under way, aided by this all-embracing term and strengthened by the success of the first one in the early decades of this century. <i>(1965,New Zealand (various authors/titles),94</i>)

<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> the courtyard of a Maori meeting-house, the centre of tribal life. [Maori]; enclosed space in front of a house; courtyard; village common (So Williams) Maori, marae pron ['marae], [ma'rae]. [often now used of the whole complex of courtyard, meeting-house, and ancillary buildings and grounds. Also in modern use as urban marae, a marae complex designed to serve Maori townspeople of mixed iwi affiliation who have moved away from their tribal areas. Maori meeting-houses as such are post-European: to be distinguished from carved houses : meeting-place the marae; but the Maori marae must be distinguished from the larger ritualistic Tahitian marae]

## marching
 
 <i>n.</i> women's formation marching as a competitive sport [It seems the trail leads back to Aucklandabout 1924 at earliest, first real exhibition probably 1926; competitions between various factories in the clothing trade. The restrictions on uniforms mentioned below were brought in to prevent big firms outspending the smallones by providing splendiferous uniforms. Organisations outside the rag trade do not seem to have been allowed in officially into Interhouse Marching until about 1954. Despite the evidence below that it started in Auckland under Jean Stevenson, Bateman's Encyclopedia says marching started in Wellington and spread to Auckland later. It must be wrong. The plot thickens. Passing through London Bookshop today I spotted Gordon Ell's new book on NZ Trivia and Kiwiana and he says Marching Girls started in Dunedin in the 1920s. have I found any early Auckland ones, nothing before 1941 in Wellington. guess is that one or other or both of Jean Stevenson and Kathleen Montgomery started them in Auckland and through the YWCA spread them rapidly throughout the main centres.]

>  New Zealanders should be proud of marching. It is the most major sport invented in this country. <i>(May 10, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),37</i>)

>  [Advt] Spectacular Interhouse Marching Drill... Pretty girls by the hundred! Massed drill movement and marching to the music of the First Battalion, Wellington Regiment. <i>(Mar 23, 1940,Dominion,5</i>)

>  [Caption] The Governor-General.. as he passed between the lines of the guard of honour from the girls' marching teams at Athletic Park on Saturday. <i>Ibid.</i> 9 One of the highlights of the display was the spectacular marching evolutions of the girls' teams. <i>(Mar 31, 1941,Dominion,5</i>)

>  <b>2</b> [Advt] 200 Girls of the Interhouse Association in Spectacular Marching and Ball Games. <i>(Mar 21, 1942,Dominion</i>)

>  [Hdg] Athletics and Interhouse Competitions... With the Wellington Pipe Band at their head, 21 girls' interhouse teams.. made a fine showing as they marched past at the sports meeting conducted at the Basin Reserve on Saturday. <i>(Mar 23, 1942,Dominion,8</i>)

>  The A.P. Smith trophy for the championship marching [was won] by the Wellington Woollen Company, the Sutherland Cup for the runners-up in the marching contest going to Fashions Ltd. <i>(Mar 23, 1943,Dominion Infotech Weekly,2</i>)

>  Before the ceremony the Air Force Band gave a short programme on the bandstand and girls' marching teams gave an exhibition. <i>(Mar 13, 1944,Dominion,6</i>)

>  [Hdg] Girls' Marching... A cold drizzle.. marred the Interhouse Girls' Marching Championship and Athletic Meeting at the Basin Reserve on Saturday... A midgets' team from Wanganui showed how well girls under the age of 11 can march. <i>(Mar 20, 1944,Dominion,6</i>)

>  Charlie Stone, a Wellington businessman, and Sergeant Major.. G. O'Leary... were responsible for getting the Wellington Interhouse Girls' Marching Association formed, though the Wellington and Kiwi Amateur Athletic Clubs, with O'Leary one of the leading lights, were the first to stage outdoor marching displays in Wellington. <i>(Nov 24, 1961,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36</i>)

>  Girls' marching as a sport or competition was started in Auckland by Miss Jean Stevenson, General Secretary of the YWCA in Auckland in the early 1920s. The idea was to give some recreation to girls who did not favour the robust sports of hockey or basketball... In due course, marching competitions came to Wellington... You can tell a marching girl by the way she carries herself - and by the absence of round shoulders... The Wellington Inter-house Marching Association was formed with rules governing costume to allow the participants to take part in running and ball-relay events as well as marching. <i>(Apr 15, 1966,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14</i>)

>  <b>CONEY</b> The highlights.. [in Auckland, in 1926] were the massed drill display of 400 girls coached by Kathleen Montgomery, and the grand march-past... This marching would develop in skill and complexity from year to year and eventually lead to the formation of a marching association in Auckland. <i>(1986,Every Girl,179</i>)

>  [Advt] Wellington Easter Show... Grand Marching Competition. <i>Ibid.</i> 6 The Inter-house girls' marching competition, which is on a bigger scale than last year, will be one of the main attractions tonight. <i>(Mar 24, 1934,Dominion,4</i>)

>  Bright costumes and attractive marching were seen at the Easter Show Stadium on Saturday evening, when the first performance for the massed trades display was given. The competing teams, of which there were ten, comprised eight girls, or, in one case, boys and a leader, all of whom were dressed by the firms they represent. <i>(Mar 26, 1934,Dominion,16</i>)

>  At the end of last season, there were 132 marching teams in New Zealand and 1346 marchers. At marching's peak, in the 1970s, there were up to 368 teams and more than 4000 marchers... <i>(Mar 16, 2002,Dominion Weekend Magazine,3</i>)

>  Despite scurrilous suggestions that marching was an Australian invention, NZ Marching asserts that the sport was introduced to Australia when New Zealand's Grenadier Guards visited there in 1953. It was not until 1977 that trans-Tasman rivals competed in the first inter-dominion championships. <i>(Mar 16, 2002,Dominion Weekend Magazine,3</i>)



## marching girl
 
 <i>n.</i> [ca1963 March J. Winchester (Wellington) `a New Zealand invention.']

>  ... not for a long time have I observed such an odd symptom of our <i>malaise </i>as the business of `marching girls'. This cult has not only established itself firmly in New Zealand: it is even being exported. ... Enquiries I have made as to the origin of this astonishing sport, or prank, ... have so far been fruitless. It has the earmarks of being an American invention, but I cannot be at all sure about this [suggests Air Force training grounds]. <i>(Jul 1952,Here & Now,9</i>) [NOTES: (A.R.D.Fairburn)]

>  <b>BRIDGES & DOWNS</b> The first record of 'Marching Girls' is in the official history of the visit of the Duke and Duchess of Cornwall and York in 1901. During the Dunedin celebrations, about 500 girls marched past as a celebration of 'girls' drill'. <i>(2000,No 8 Wire: The Best of Kiwi Ingenuity,132</i>)

>  Part of the answer may also be found in an innocent exhibitionism; marching girls are really modelled on the drum majorettes who strut and prance at the head of American processions. <i>(Mar 21, 1958,Listener (New Zealand Listener),10</i>)

>  [Caption] Marching girls in a drill display at Basin Reserve, Wellington, in 1936... It is not easy to win a marching medal these days, so when you next see a marching girl with a display of medals that would make a Field Marshal envious you will realise that the walking jingle represents many hours of hard practice. <i>(Nov 24, 1961,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36</i>)

>  You can tell a marching girl by the way she carries herself - and by the absence of round shoulders. <i>(Apr 15, 1966,Listener (New Zealand Listener),14</i>)

>  The psychological explanation of the 'marching girls' cult is probably complex. <i>(Jul 1952,Here & Now,2(10) : 9</i>)

>  <b>MASON</b> "Tell me," I asked, "why playing in an orchestra is better than marching girls?" She turned over lazily. "Because they are engaged in making something bigger than themselves, and they are more potent together than they are alone." <i>(1986,Every Kind of Weather,249</i>)

>  <b>MASON</b> The marching girl display paraded something like suppressed fury, for all its skill and panache. <i>(1986,Every Kind of Weather,250</i>)

>  Fiona Samuel, The Marching Girls writer, has always thought marching teams are ""neat".... The Marching Girls, which is as much about the lives of a group of New Zealand women as it is about marching, fitted the bill exactly. Even if they are called marching "girls". <i>(Oct 24, 1987,Listener (New Zealand Listener),21</i>)

>  Marching girls have featured on postage stamps, been the subject of a television drama series, and even had a punk band named after them. <i>(Mar 16, 2002,Dominion Weekend Magazine,3</i>)

>  <i>(Dec 10, 1954,Listener (New Zealand Listener)</i>) [NOTES: 1954 Dec 10 Listener D. Glover in 1961 Reid Kiwi Laughs 182-183]

>  <i>(Nov 24, 1961,Listener (New Zealand Listener),36</i>)

>  Nor have we invented any games that I know of - or did we breed the first marching girls? <i>(1961,Distance Looks Our Way,36</i>) [NOTES: (Sinclair)]

>  <b>TURNER</b> In sport ... <i>marching girls</i> appear to have been a New Zealand idea, though already on July 1952 when A.R.D. Fairburn wrote about them in the periodical <i>Here and Now</i> (Vol. 2, no. 10, p. 9), the origin of the idea could not easily be traced. <i>(1966,English Language in Aust. & NZ, The,176</i>)

>  <b>LELAND</b> <i>(1980,Personal Kiwi-Yankee Dictionary, A,63</i>)

>  <i>marching girl NZ & Austral.</i> girl trained to march in formation. <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary,459</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 299]]

>  I always write about real life, though sometimes indirectly - whereas something as direct and visible as a team of marching girls never quite manages to seem like real life to me. <i>(May 22, 1982,Listener (New Zealand Listener),87</i>)

## Marion
 
 (=Tribe of Marion) <i>n.</i> Early nickname for `Frenchman'; in pl. `The French'. cf WIWI (from Marion du Fresne, a French Captain killed, with his crew, in a Maori revenge attack, 182?) esp. the TRIBE OF MARION, trans. from Maori

>  <b>LANG</b> One of the natives ..... perceived that M. Lacoste was not an Englishman, and asked Mr. Mair `if he were not a Marion' to which Mr Mair replied in the affirmative. ## mark
 
 <i>v.</i>

>  <b>BOOTH</b> A good hand can cut and mark two thousand lambs per day... <i>(1912,Five Years in NZ,26</i>)

>  <i>Mark.</i>- To <i>ear-m.</i> Now a frequent euphemism for cut and tail (q.v.). (C.) <i>(Nov 4, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>459</b> <i>mark ... NZ & Austral</i>. ear-mark (lamb, calf, etc.), castrate (lamb). <i>(1986,NZ Pocket Oxford Dictionary</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.]]



 
 <i>v.</i> to castrate (and often dock the tail of) a lamb, or to castrate a calf.

>  <b>T.C. KIERNAN</b> 48 sheep shorn, 3 lambs marked. <i>(Jan 28, 1879,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1879 Jan 28 T.C. Kiernan Diary in 1921 Guthrie-Smith Tutira 125]

>  <b>FERGUSON</b> But by-and-bye the overseer/ [168] Rode out to learn the shepherds' cheer./ It now was time to mark the lambs,/ <i>(1883,Castle Gay,167</i>)

>  Marking lambs all day from home paddocks. Most miserable result. <i>(Oct 7, 1886,Chudleigh Diary,348,1950 ed.</i>)

>  We have marked nearly 1,300 Merino lambs, ... <i>(Dec 17, 1903,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1903 Dec 17 letter in 1978 Hayes Toss Of a Coin 78]

>  I commenced marking lambs today. <i>(Sep 28, 1906,Chudleigh Diary,436,1950 ed.</i>)

>  I commenced marking lambs today. <i>(Sep 28, 1906,Chudleigh Diary,436,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>PERRY</b> [caption] Temporary yards for marking lambs. <i>(1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,79</i>)

>  <i>(1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,463</i>) [NOTES: also June 516/2]

>  <b>McLEOD</b> ...800 lambs to catch and mark,... <i>(1951,High Country,19</i>)

>  <b>TOMLINSON</b> We mustered ... several other blocks, marking about 9,000 lambs, and we did another 3,000 at shearing time. ... When we finished the lamb marking we returned to Tarndale ... <i>(1968,Remembered Trails,41</i>)

>  <b>GRUNDY</b> The cattle are sorted out, and the bulls are marked. ... A few good specimens are sent back unmarked for breeding purposes. <i>(1968,Who'd Marry a Doctor?,66</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Calf marking is another major job that is done is in Bush Gully yards. ... I was interested to find that all the calves - marked in March and fairly sizable - are done in the bail ... . The marking cradle was tried but did not find favour. <i>(1973,Big Country,65,1977 ed.</i>)

>  <b>MEREDITH</b> A little further up the [East] coast the Maoris have a flock of very "scabby' sheep, which roam over a large area of land. These sheep are all long-tailed, and have never been marked, except on their ears. <i>(1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,145,1935 ed.</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>FITTON</b> Several marks of Adelaide [wool] have been sold which equal any we have seen from this colony; and we have a general improvement ... in condition in which the wool is brought to market. <i>(1856,New Zealand (various authors/titles),232</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) to castrate, earmark and tail lambs and calves [originally S.I.]

>  <b>CHUDLEIGH</b> I commenced marking lambs today. <i>(Sep 28, 1906,Diary,438</i>) [NOTES: (1950)]

>  <b>MEREDITH</b> These sheep are all long-tailed, and have never been marked, except on their ears. <i>(1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,145</i>) [NOTES: (1935)]

>  <b>DEANS</b> The hardest day I can recall was about 1901 when the lambs from 3,000 Merino ewes running on the Bush Gully block had to be marked in one day. <i>(1964,Pioneers on Port Cooper Plains,114</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i>

>  <b>HYDE</b> After sundown, still slouching in the streets, he felt the muzzle of a gun stuck into his back ... and a man said softly: `You shout for the boys, or you'll be put on the mark.' [?pay up, or take the consequences] <i>(1938,Nor the Years Condemn,214</i>)

## Marseille tile
 
 <i>n.</i> a burnt-clay roofing tile, commonly used esp. on bungalows and State House. [Jim writes: Introduced to NZ about 1901 and imported until 1924, after which they were made locally. See Salmond <i>Old NZ Houses</i> p 122 etc. An account of the development of the Marseilles tile roof in Australia is in Robin Boyd <i>Australia's Home</i> p. 151-153. Despite its European name and the original provenance of the tile, this term is not in British dictionaries I have seen. NSOD has only <i>Marseille ware</i> - a type of pottery produced in Marseilles during the 17th and 18th centuries. DEH adds: researching family geneology, I encountered a ship from Marseilles via Genoa to Sydney or NZ in 1909 from Marseille with a cargo of tiles. Many Kelburn houses have Marseilles tiles]

## Mascot of HMS New Zealand, the
 
 <i>phr.</i>

>  <b>FRASER & McGIBBON</b> <i>MASCOT OF H.M.S. NEW ZEALAND, THE</i>: The Maori `Piu-piu,' or cloak of black and white strips of flax and feathers, and the carved greenstone amulet figure, ("Tiki") worn round the neck (similar to the old battle insignia of Maori chiefs) presented to the battleship <i>New Zealand</i>. They were given by an old Maori Chief in 1913, with the injunction that they must always be worn when the ship was in action, the chief prophesying that they would keep the ship from harm. Both "Piu-piu' and `Tiki' were worn at the Battle of Jutland by the Captain - to the great satisfaction of the crew, who, it is told, before the battle began took special measures to find out that the Captain was actually wearing the ship's mascot. On another occasion, when an action seemed imminent, the <i>New Zealand</i> mascot was also worn. On that occasion, word was specially passed round the decks among the men - `It's all right, he's got 'em on!' The <i>New Zealand</i> at Jutland escaped with only one shell hit, and had no casualties. Writing home after Jutland an officer said: "This ship bore a charmed life and suffered to the smallest extent though we were right in it the whole time.' <i>(1925,Soldier and Sailor Words,152</i>)

 <i>n.</i> a Maori cloak often of woven flax (cf flax mat, maori mat) [Williams (313) 2. >  The third sort of Ahou [cloak] seemed to be made of the Cloth Plant coarsely beat out or of a kind of narrow Sedge or course [sic] grass- ... the ends of the stuff of about a foot long were left out so as to form a thick covering layer over layer, and very much resembled what Seamen call thrum-Matts. <i>(Oct 11, 1769,Cook's Journals,1/572,1955 ed.</i>) [NOTES: 1769 Oct 11 W.B. Monkhouse in 1955 Cook Journal I-572]

>  <b>HUTT</b> Matai beer was described by a Taihape newspaper in 1912 as tasting "like used machine oil... When a deep swig is absorbed, one has all the sensations of having swallowed a lighted kerosene stove." <i>(1999,Maori & Alcohol,14</i>) [NOTES: see McKay <i>Puborama</i> 1961, p. 95]

>  ... I dimly remember as a youngster in the days when the Forty-Mile Bush was still standing, such a drink as `matai beer' was sometimes spoken of amongst bushmen. Apparently it was made from the sap of the matai tree, extracted by the simple process of boring an auger-hole in the trunk. ... Can any old-timer axeman give any information concerning this liquor. <i>(Dec 10, 1920,Quick March,13</i>)

>  When I was a boy I lived in Carterton, and that was in the 'sixties, when there was little else than bush there ... I have frequently drunk the matai beer which gushes out of the centre of the tree when the axemen get to the heart. The flavour varies, but always has something of the tang of resin about it, though it is not at all a bad drink. ... I never heard of this matai beer being intoxicating; ... <i>(Feb 10, 1921,Quick March,13</i>)

>  <b>MACKAY</b> In the rip-roaring times of the King Country, Matai beer was a favourite with those who were strong enough and tough enough to drink it. It went out of favour when `cruisers' for the various timber mills complained that much good yellow pine was being ruined through the number of deep axe cuts and even auger holes in the standing trees, made to let the potent juice run into waiting pannikins or buckets. The favourite recipe for this form of wood alcohol represented the addition of three or four cupsful of the sap to each gallon of `ordinary' liquid refreshment. That the resultant mixture had a pretty hefty kick to it may be judged from this description handed in to the Taihape newspaper (1912): `Matai beer is the term used to describe a certain brand or grade of alcoholic brew. It may be identified easily. It smells like an ancient bar room the morning after. It tastes like used machine oil, only a very low grade of machine oil. <i>(1961,Puborama,95</i>)

>  <b>OWEN & PERKINS</b> But [bushmen] used to make concoctions of their own, and the most popular ... was matai beer. ... When you felled a big matai, a really mature black pine ... you would see the main artery in the heart of the tree gushing out the life liquid. ... It wasn't the sap; this was not related to that. It was a pure clear liquid, and it gushed out like the main artery gushing blood. But that used to be prized, and it would be caught in a billy. That was really something. It was beautiful and cool and sweet to drink as it was, but some of the blokes used to bung in maybe a handful of raisins and sugar and cork her up and let her ferment, and whether that fluid had any other properties in it or not I don't know, but you could get quite a potent drink from it. <i>(1986,Speaking for Ourselves,65</i>) [NOTES: (Bob Edwards, bushman)]

>  <b>FULLER</b> MATAI BEER [title] I have been told by old bushmen and Maoris about making beer from the sap of the matai tree ... Apparently when the tree was being cut down the watery sap was collected, more water was added and also some ordinary beer, or yeast. It was left to ferment and was reputed to be quite strong though I have not been able to find any written evidence of this. <i>(1978,Maori Food and Cookery,83</i>)

## Matariki
 
 <i>n.</i> (Te Matariki) the Pleiades, the heliacal rising of which in early winter marks the Maori New Year. [Jim writes: now an occasional celebration by urban as well as rural Maori. Known to me from posters etc. Not in DNZE.]

>  One whakatauki, or proverb, describes this time as Matariki ahunga nui: Matariki, provider of plentiful food... Matariki marked a turning point in the gardening year... The appearance of Matariki is auspicious for predicting the coming year's harvests. <i>(Jun 5, 2004,Dominion,E17</i>)

>  The Maori new year started on June 23, after the first new moon following since the yearly reappearance above the horizon before dawn of the Pleiades star cluster (Maori : Matariki). <i>(Dec 17, 2001,Evening Post,7</i>)

>  My apologies.. if I did not make it sufficiently clear in describing Matariki that the celebration of a New Year marked by the winter solstice is the "tradition" that links it with Hogmanay and the Saturnalia. It did not occur to me that this might be misconstrued as a suggestion that Maori had been celebrating Matariki here for millennia. <i>(Jul 12, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener),9</i>)

>  Matariki is a time for harvesting and Thornley says it is a good time to gather herbs from the bush... "It's a good time to pick pikopiko. Matariki is a time for putting the past to rest and looking forward to the future." <i>(Jun 25, 2003,Capital Times,18</i>)

>  Winter might not be the easiest time of the year to rise before dawn, but it's the only chance to see Matariki, a cluster of stars that heralds the Maori New Year... Matariki is celebrated differently by each iwi,. but the New Year begins with the first new moon after the appearance of Matariki. <i>(May 27, 2004,Wellington Contact,1</i>)

>  Towards the end of May each year the constellation Matariki, also known as the Pleiades, rises on the north-east horizon around half an hour before dawn. <i>(Aug 2001,Absolutely Positively Wellington,10</i>)

>  [Hdg] Matariki celebrations continue at Te Papa... In the last week of May, the star cluster Matariki, or Pleiades, appears in our dawn sky. For most iwi, the Maori New year begins with the first new moon after the appearance of Matariki. <i>(Jun 14, 2001,City Voice,4</i>)

>  <b>PARK</b> At Te Kuiti I never saw the Pleiades because of the hills. Years afterwards, when I lived on the broad plains, I saw that heliacal rising, a handful of sparks on the horizon, until the sun blew them out. Mr Tawhai called them Te Matariki. <i>(1992,Fence Around the Cuckoo,70</i>)

>  But what is Matariki and why has this ancient tradition, which hasn't been much practised by Maori for the past 150 years, suddenly taken off again? Matariki is the Maori name for the beautiful little cluster of stars that is commonly known as the Pleiades or the Seven Sisters, Roughly translated, it means "little-eyes".... At the end of May, Matariki reappears in the morning sky, rising just before dawn... So Matariki is linked to the universal celebration of midwinter. It's the antipodean equivalent of the Scots' hogmanay or the Chinese New Year - in fact it has traditions that go back further than the Roman Saturnalia. <i>(Jun 7, 2003,Listener (New Zealand Listener)</i>)

>  At one stage during the party she was Mr Reid sitting ... playing `matchsticks' ... The game involved trying to throw a match into the other person's drink. If this happened, the loser had to drink a full glass of whisky. They called the game `skull'. <i>(Dec 12, 1979,Dominion,1</i>)

>  Other well-known [drinking] games are Hokonui Swindle, Bottles, Fluffy Ducks, Bunnies are Hovering, Cardinal Huff, All Blacks, Matches, and The Amazing Grimaldi Brothers. All these games involve either a complicated intellectual exercise, tongue twisters, mathematical calculations or aerobatics in a confined space; High Candelabras for example, involves intoxicated individuals attempting to traverse the four walls of a room without touching the floor. <i>(Mar 13, 1988,Dominion Sunday Times,16</i>)



## matchhead
 
 <i>n.</i> [Kolstad says there was an entry of "matchhead moss" <i> Cladonia cristatella</i>) written but not included in Vol.3 of Dictionary of American Regional English. Kerry Carman (Sep. 2000) writes : This is a very localised Southland/Otago colloquialism for the Grape Hyacinth <i>Muscari armeniacum</i>. The only literary reference I can give you, apart from Frame, is from Invercargill writer Olive Dunn's <i>Delights of Colour in a New Zealand Garden </i>p. 16. Other Southern writers such as Essie Summers also use the term I am told but I can not supply a reference. The origin remains a mystery but it may stem from the old blue topped wax Vesta matches. Dianne Bardsley says she knew the term well from the Wairarapa, but it is not known in Taranaki.]

>  <b>SUMMERS</b> Matchheads formed a solid blue edge to the border. <i>(1976,Gold of Noon, The,142</i>)

>  Matchheads could stem from the old blue-topped wax Vesta matches - which were once widely known in the area. <i>(Dec 9, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),45</i>)

>  <b>FRAME</b> "...masses of spring flowers - daffodils, matchheads, crocuses, along the banks of the creek that flowed through the property." <i>(1989,Complete Autobiography, The,177</i>)

>  <b>DUNN</b> What a selection to choose from: crocus, matchheads, chionodoxa.. and nemesia. <i>(1990,Delights of Colour in a NZ Garden,16</i>)
