## mate
 
 <i>n.</i> a) a habitual companion or fellow worker: `my mate and I worked the shearing sheds around here for almost 30 years'. b) hence a common form of address (= friend). -->perhaps from early whalers and sailors, adopted by goldminers and early colonial labourers `partner and friend', developing into `friend'; and also, through a form of address, to `fellow; JOKER; SPORT'. (cf MATING vbl n.) [AND 1. a. equal partner in an enterprise 1838; b. go mates 1876 2. acquaintance, person engaged in the same activity 1841 3 ... a sworn friend 1891 4. a mode of address, often to a casual acquaintance 1843

>  He [McKenzie] stated that he had no mates with him, although traces of other men could be seen... After talking with him ... the dogs began to ko-hi. Upon being questioned what he [McKenzie] was kohi-'ng for, he stated that `they were his mates,' but witness was not to be afraid, they would not hurt him. <i>(Apr 18, 1855,Lyttelton Times,6</i>)

>  ... we are now satisfied that we have a good paying claim; my mates think that now we have not less than 48 ounces which we have got in these six days. <i>(Aug 5, 1857,Lyttelton Times,5</i>)

>  He asked if I or my mates intended going back to Mangawatiri. <i>(1861,McLean Papers,19/12</i>) [NOTES: (Moffitt.)]

>  <b>HARPER</b> Me and my mate here.... <i>(1861,Letters from Canterbury, NZ,64,1914 ed.</i>)

>  ... myself and mates were ahead of the others, and on coming to this place I took my `swag' and laid it on the bank. <i>(1863,AJHR,1862 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (Michael Grogan, prospector.) [1862] 1863 AJ D/6/5 Pyke, Report on Goldfields]

>  <b>WALKER</b> He [the miner] was very civil, told us that two of his mates had followed a man to see if they could find a new rush, ... <i>(Jan 12, 1863,Journal and Letters (Walker)</i>) [NOTES: (Central Otago)]

>  <b>HODDER</b> My mates, or `chums', [among the diggers] were a queer set. <i>(1862,Memories of NZ Life,F1</i>)

>  <b>MONEY</b> ... he was as good a mate as any man could wish for in the bush ..., and we got on very well together during the seven or eight months that we were mates. <i>(1871,Knocking About in NZ,73</i>)

>  <b>BARKER</b> The pride and delight of the [shearer's] <i>mate</i> was greater than mine. <i>(1874,Station Life in NZ,104</i>)

>  <b>BAINES</b> These men [i.e. the floating population] usually have `mates' and are hired in pairs. [timber-mill] <i>(1874,Edward Crewe,188</i>)

>  <b>WHITWORTH</b> At the time ... there were three chaps, mates, who'd been digging somewhere about the head of the Arahura, came down here timber getting. <i>(1875,Cobb's Box,5</i>)

>  <b>MONEY</b> [I] hunted up a mate ... [and] `wired into' the work. <i>(1871,Knocking About in NZ,147</i>)

>  [We] fell in with an encampment ... mostly occupied by one man, the only representative of a prospecting party, which had left one of their mates behind to look after ... the horses during their absence. <i>(1879,Geology of the Provinces of Canterbury & Westland,100</i>)

>  <b>BELL</b> Harry and his mate had now been working in the bush districts of the North Island [on contract bushfalling] for two or three seasons. <i>Ibid.</i> 85 [He] had tried his luck for a time on the gold-fields of the West Coast, where he had picked up Big George for a mate. <i>(1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,14</i>)

>  <b>BARKER</b> I selected as my partner a very decent young farmer who lives near ... and is at work branding our sheep all shearing-time. The pride and delight of his <i>mate</i> was much greater than my partner's; he stood near his friend prompting him through the mazes of the most extraordinary quadrille ... <i>(1866,Station Life in NZ,104,1870 ed.</i>)

>  <b>NESFIELD</b> The out-station that I went to was about seventeen miles from the head-station. ... I was particularly fortunate in having a very decent companion for a `mate'. <i>(1881,Chequered Career,36</i>)

 <i>adj.</i> dead [ORIGIN: Maori]

 <i>n.</i> ill health or death coming to one who has broken the law of tapu; also called Maori sickness [ORIGIN: Maori, (cf WF `matie' n. (1) + (2))]

<b>4</b> <i>n.</i> one whose loyalty one can depend on often used instead of PAL, etc.; often refers to a faithful friendship between two men, and the term then implies loyalty of the most constant kind; a term essential to the Australian and New Zealand vocabulary - [1951 16+ F 23 Marlborough C. 29 MATE [friendship term] -->1951 15 M 3 Marlborough C. 29 MATE -->1960 18C M B11 Nelson Boys C. 29 MATE -->1960 18C F B12 Horowhenua C. 29 MATE -->1951 15 M 23 Wellington H.S. 29 MATE (7) -->1951 16+ M 10 St Mary's, Wgton 29 MATE (12) -->1951 14-16+ M 32 St Bede's, Chch 29 MATE (22) -->1951 15 F 3 Marlborough C. 29 MATE (4) -->1951 16+ M 10 St Mary's, Wgton 29 MATE (5) -->1951 14-16+ M 26 Wellington H.S. 29 MATE (20) -->1953 14-17 M A12 Thames DHS 29 MATE [M10] -->1984 16-17F E4 Pakuranga Coll. 29 MATE [F12 M21] -->1984 14 F E122 Wgton Girls C. 29 MATE [F6]]

<b>5</b> <i>n.</i> for acquaintance or strangers in a passing exchange, esp. LISTEN (etc) MATE (cf CHIEF, SPORT) rarely MATEY [-->1951 14 M 10 Wellington H.S. 11 MATE [addressing an equal] -->1953 14-15 M A11 Thames DHS 11 MATE [4] -->1984 17 F E Pakuranga Coll. 11 MATE [F1 M9]]

## mate Maori
 
 <i>n.</i> Maori sickness

>  <b>BEAGLEHOLE</b> The sign most often taken to indicate this sort of sickness is that the sickness does not appear to be yielding readily to ordinary Maori or to pakeha methods of treatment. It is then considered to be a Maori sickness - a `mate Maori' as the phrase is commonly used - and for sure, safe, and quick results, treatment should be referred to a Maori expert, a tohunga, either male or female, who will use a combination of religious prayer, seance-possession, and magic to restore the sick person to health. <i>(1946,Some Modern Maoris,219</i>)

>  <b>HENDERSON</b> To break the law of<i> tapu</i> was to die of <i>mate Maori</i>, the sickness caused by an uneasy Maori conscience or the influx of demons. <i>(1963,Ratana,9,1972 ed.</i>)

>  If a Maori is genuinely disturbed, in Maori terms, the answer again is to restore their mauri (life force), as for physical illness. This is particularly true for <i>mate</i> Maori, Maori sickness, which arises from spiritual and social causes, not physical ones (Pakehas would call it psychosomatic). <i>(May 1987,Metro,100</i>)

>  <b>BINNEY et al.</b> Inexplicable sickness, <i>mate Maori</i>, is often attributed to evil forces living in the human body; their extraction, possible only by faith in the healer, is a major part of the role of a tohunga. <i>(1979,Mihaia,25</i>)

>  Her son had refused to go to hospital for treatment of his mental condition, after an earlier visit to a local doctor. It has been revealed the youth was angry over such things as social and political issues in New Zealand and South Africa, as well as the nuclear issue. There is a suggestion that the youth also suffered from a form of spiritual illness, called mate Maori. The youth had been to see a Maori spiritual healer, a tohunga, but his mother said tapu forbids her from discussing his diagnosis. <i>(Apr 13, 1986,NZ Times,3</i>)

>  In 2000, Tariana Turia, who was then associate Maori affairs minister [sic], questioned whether psychologists had the appropriate training to deal with issues such as Maori sickness (mate Maori). Victoria University's head of Maori studies [sic], Peter Adds, said mate Maori was a fairly common condition. <i>(Mar 10, 2007,Dominion Post,A1</i>)

## meeting house
 
 <i>n.</i> a Maori meeting house: the concept is post-European: distinguish from earlier CARVED HOUSE, which often seemed to be a chiefly dwelling or used for a special purpose: check Cook etc. call them CHIEF'S HOUSES

>  <b>TINNE</b> ... enjoying dry ... quarters at the great `whare-puna', or meeting-house, of the tribe. <i>(1873,Wonderland of the Antipodes,9</i>)

>  <b>FINLAYSON</b> 8. `the meeting-house'. Meeting houses have often been the focus of community effort and pride. They are long halls used for meetings and for the accommodation of visitors. They have a verandah at the entrance with a carved gabled front and are richly decorated inside, with patterned reed panels, with black and white painted scrolls on the rafters, and with carvings or paintings of ancestors and incidents in the mythological history of the people on whose marae the meeting-house is built. Supporting the ridge-pole is a centre-post on which are figures of ancestors. The floor is often covered with flax matting, and visitors take off their shoes before entering. Another meeting house is described in the first part of `Hemi's Daughter'. <i>(1973,Brown Man's Burden,135</i>)

>  <b>SHADBOLT</b> "But all the rooms with this ward overlook the Maori meeting house,' the sister said. <i>(1965,Among the Cinders,45</i>)

>  <b>BAXTER</b> On the concrete path to the meeting house/ It was the women who cried out,/ <i>(1979,Collected Poems,400,1967 ed.</i>)

>  <b>THOMAS</b> The meeting house, situated in the centre of the kainga, was the usual type of those days with walls and roof thatched with raupo and nikau, no floor and dividing partitions. <i>(1970,Way Up North,4</i>)

>  <b>JENKIN</b> The building itself was unusual in that all the figures in the meetinghouse had carved skirts, or <i>piu piu. Ibid.</i> They were told ...of the reputation of the <i>wharepuni</i> (meeting house) at Matahiwi. <i>(1970,NZ Mysteries,108</i>)

>  Prime examples [of surviving traditional technology] are the techniques of building and decorating meeting houses and of making piupiu (dance skirts). <i>(1984,Te Maori,30</i>)

>  <b>OWEN & PERKINS</b> In those days [c1890s] they had what was known as the `Maori wedding', which was not legal to the Pakeha, but was a binding thing among the Maori people themselves. A young couple would decide that they wanted to become man and wife, and they would have to tell their parents they wanted this. Well, at night-time everyone would congregate in the meetinghouse [the matter would be discussed, the boy and girl would be asked whether they wanted to marry, and they would take each other in front of all their people]. <i>(1986,Speaking for Ourselves,109</i>) [NOTES: (Florence Harsant, Taupo)]

>  <i>meeting house</i> large,<i> usu</i>. decorated Maori tribal hall (also<i> wharepuni</i>) <i>(1985,Collins Compact Dictionary,305</i>) [NOTES: [nf. 1982 Collins Concise Eng. Dict.; nf. 1986 NZPOD]]

>  Wood used for carving and building carries with it the spirit of the tree, the spirit of place including the name of the place, and the spirit of the carvers who create the powerful images of tribal ancestors which decorate wharenui (meeting houses). ... >  Ironically, the most abundant of all New Zealand flounders, the witch or megrim, is useless for eating because of its multitude of long thin hair-like bones and thin watery flesh. The priest spreads out a holy mat with marks on it which means something they have great faith in. He kneels down beside the mat, then a row of worshippers kneel all round him, with another row bending over them, and another row standing behind them. The worshippers throw their offerings on to the holy mat, and the priest places two coins on a short piece of polished wood which he calls a kip, and raising his eyes to the sky, he throws up the coins as an offering to Allah. ## milking cow
 
 <i>n.</i> (mining)

>  <b>McARA</b> <i>Caving method</i>: Also known as the `milking cow'; it applied to an area of several acres where the Mine Lake is now. The method started with the collapse of the large arches on the Martha reef about No. 1 shaft, and was later systematically developed by a series of sub-levels on Nos 7, 8 and 9 levels which were used to weaken this section of country and cause it to run so that it could be drawn off through chutes. It operated for a quarter-century and is conservatively estimated to have yielded over a million tons of good run-of-mine grade ore. <i>Ibid.</i> 327 <i>Milking Cow or Caving Block</i>: (See also caving method). A block of country between Nos 1 and 6 shafts and Junction Road, where the Mine Lake is now, which originally contained a network of large reefs and which collapsed after the removal of undergound support pillars and arches and became a caving area. It is estimated that over 1,000,000 tons of ore of good grade was obtained on Nos 7 and 8 levels by caving methods during a period of 25 years. <i>(1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),314</i>)

>  Theoretically, a Morrinsville trainer could give one of his horses a sizeable milk-shake, raise its level to say 35, and still be confident of escaping detection if he raced in Auckland. <i>(Apr 13, 1997,Sunday Star Times,B13</i>)

>  Veterinary opinion is still divided on whether milkshakes improve the performance of horses. <i>(Feb 12, 1995,Sunday Star Times,B5</i>)

>  [This] experiment casts doubts on harness racing authorities' previously held belief that only an administration of sodium bicarbonate (a milkshake) can cause horses' bicarb levels to rise at the track. <i>(Nov 26, 1995,Sunday Star Times,B18</i>)



 
 <i>v.</i>

>  [He] told the Tribunal It was "practical but inappropriate to use venous blood to decide if horses had been milkshaked. <i>(Apr 13, 1997,Sunday Star Times,B13</i>)

>  The conference relied on statistical probability that a horse had been "milk-shaked"... Horses with lower bicarbonate levels which were being "milk-shaked" could still pass the tests. <i>(Feb 9, 1995,Dominion,18</i>)

>  The suggestion that he deliberately milkshaked the horse again so that her level would be high in case officials visited him was laughable. <i>(Nov 26, 1995,Sunday Star Times,B18</i>)

## milkshaking
 
 <i>n.</i> doping racehorses

>  Apparently racing authorities are trying to crack down on "milkshaking". the banned practice of giving harness racers a dose of sodium carbonate before a race to stop them tiring. <i>(Apr 15, 1991,Listener (New Zealand Listener),80</i>)

>  A former Gore stablehand was arrested and held in jail being caught red-handed milkshaking a horse in the United States... Milkshaking is the illegal practice of tubing a mixture into a horse's stomach to delay the onset of lactic acid buildup in the muscles and enhance stamina. <i>(Feb 29, 2004,Sunday Star Times,B14</i>)

>  Testing for bicarbonate, or the practice commonly known as milkshaking, continued on an intermittent basis without revealing a positive. <i>(Jul 18, 2005,Dominion Post,D6</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i>

>  Soon after the crackdown on milkshaking, Brady was forced to sell Franco Ice to fund his legal fees. <i>(Aug 4, 2002,Sunday Star Times,B14</i>)

>  Three vets have been found guilty in galloping's first detected case of milkshaking... [They] were found to have administered, or cause to be administered, sodium bicarbonate for the purpose of affecting performance. <i>(Dec 4, 1994,Sunday Star Times,B13</i>)

>  Kiwi trainers are cheating more than anyone else in the world, with the milkshaking of horses still widespread. <i>(Apr 13, 1997,Sunday Star Times,B13</i>)

>  The milkshaking debate still goes on in the trotting industry. <i>(Jan 1992,North & South,20</i>)

>  Dosing horses with [sodium bicarbonate] is known in the industry as "milk-shaking". <i>(Feb 9, 1995,Dominion,18</i>)

>  [She] did not show the same characteristic rise in level associated with milkshaking. <i>(Nov 26, 1995,Sunday Star Times,B18</i>)

## mimosa
 
 <i>n.</i> KOWHAI [AND Acacia 1959] (an occasional and mistaken name - occas. NATIVE MIMOSA from the yellow colour of both Austral, wattle and kowhai blooms)

>  <b>WAKEFIELD</b> Everywhere are to be seen ... the beautiful mimosa, called Kohai, (<i>Edwardsia microphylla</i>,) covered with clusters of yellow flowers. [but cp op. cit. 152 `some mimosas from N.S.W. [have been introduced]'] <i>(1848,Handbook for New Zealand, The,144</i>)

>  <b>LINDSAY</b> <i>S. tetraptera</i>, Aiton, var. <i>microphylla,</i> Jacq. ... The `Kowhai' of the North Island Maori; the `Kowai' of settlers, - or as the word is variously corrupted and spelt by them, - `Goai' or `Ghoai,' `Goa' or `Ghoa.' According to Hector, the type is known to Otago Maoris as `Houma;' while the term `Kowhai' is applied to var. <i>grandiflora</i> in common with its other varieties. Var. <i>microphylla </i>is also sometimes designated by the colonists the Native `Laburnum' or `Mimosa,' from the similarity of its foliage, in the arboreous condition, to that of these familiar ... European trees. <i>(1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,73</i>)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> occas. name in NZ (? now obsolete) for Australian wattle (from the former scientific name)



 
<b>2</b> <i>n.</i> occas. name in NZ (? now obsolete) for Australian wattle (from the former scientific name)

## Ministry
 
 <i>n.</i> In New Zealand until quite recently (Ministry of Works, 19 ), only the former of the two main `governmental' senses of Ministry was commonly used: OED 5 from 1710, the body of ministers forming the government' eg. the Seddon ministry, etc. As the name of a Stare department (OED 6, from 1877) it was introduced when the name of the `Public Works Department (see P.W.D.) was for various reasons changed to Ministry of Works. Since then the reorganisation and extension of responsibilities of the Transport Department has given a new Ministry of Transport. -->`Ministry' is felt to be a more inclusive (perhaps grander) name than `department' in the NZ State Services system. (Based partly on a note by R. Mason) -->cf EWD 5.

For a long time it has been known to the Maori and to Europeans that our New Zealand Whitebait is the young of a native freshwater fish commonly known as Minnow, or Inanga or Hiwi to the Maori, and erroneously called a Trout. ... The early settlers called it Maori Trout, Native Trout, Rock Trout and Minnow. But it is not a Trout. Nor is it a Minnow, through it resembles the English freshwater Minnow. While the name Trout is not correct, it is and will always be known as such by farmers and naturalists. In the Bay of Plenty, Whitebait is known to the Maori as Porohoe. <i>(1956,NZ Fishes: An Identification Guide,118</i>)

>  <b>WILLIAMS</b> <i>I[i]nanga, inanga</i>, n. <i>1. Whitebait</i>, the adult of the minnow, <i>Galaxias attenuatus</i>(also the fry), and the fry of the smelt, <i>Retropinna retropinna.</i> ... Maoris distinguish between <i>inanga papa</i>, a variety of smelt, <i>Retropinna</i>, and <i>inanga tu[u]tuna,</i> a spotted variety of minnow, <i>Galaxias. </i> <i>(1971,Dictionary of the Maori Language,77</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> MINNOW Another name for the `Inanga'. Given by early settlers because of its resemblance to the English minnow, - of which it is no relative. <i>(1981,Fisherman's Bible,288</i>)

>  <b>PHILLIPPS</b> NEW ZEALAND MINNOW (<i>Galaxias attenuatus</i>). <i>(1925,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,8/291</i>)

>  <b>PHILLIPPS</b> NEW ZEALAND MINNOW <i>Galaxias attenuatus</i> (Jenyns) ... This is the inanga of the Maori; but the term is not used in the same sense by all tribes. ## mismother
 
<b>1</b> <i>v.</i> (Rural) to unsuccessfully re-unite ewe and lamb after a docking muster etc.

>  <b>OVERTON</b> ...great care should be taken not to mismother the lambs when approaching the yards. <i>(1949,Fifty Years Sheep Farming,97</i>)

>  <b>MILLS ET AL</b> Ewes with lambs will not 'follow on' the same as dry sheep will. Instinctively they know that once in a mob they will mis-mother. Under no circumstances should ewes and lambs be bunched to the extent that they mis-mother. <i>(1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,85</i>)

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> The manager of an adjoining station once told me that he saw about 5,000 Merino ewes and lambs yarded on one occasion by an inexperienced man, and about 200 were smothered before the men started tailing. Then they let the ewes and lambs out on to a big block, <i>yard by yard as they finished,</i> the result being that fully 500 lambs were mis-mothered, some of the ewes being miles away before the mob was through. <i>(1940,Te Waimate,114,1954 ed.</i>)



## mismothered
 
<b>1</b> <i>adj.</i> (Rural) [of mother and offspring pairs] unsuccessful in re-pairing following a muster.

>  <b>MCLEOD</b> As the sheep get bunched together the lambs begin to get mismothered ... <i>(1951,NZ High Country,25</i>)

>  <b>MILLS ET AL</b> As they are allowed to string through the gate and away, a proportion of mis-mothered lambs .. will appear to have been abandoned. [mis-mothered] <i>(1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,98</i>)



## mismothering
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) the unsuccessful re-pairing of ewes and lambs following a muster etc.

>  <b>MILLS ET AL</b> Maybe at times some mis-mothering will take place at the gate as the flow of the mob thickens. <i>(1964,Practical Guide to Handling Dogs and Stock,86</i>)

>  <b>MACINTOSH</b> We preferred to bring our ewes and lambs in paddock by paddock to avoid mismothering. <i>(1974,Never a Dull Moment,111</i>)

>  <b>GORDON</b> The mobs were too large, the mismothering was very bad and shifting lambs to other paddocks at a very early age was causing further mismothering. <i>(1987,People, Places & Paddocks,60</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> The whole aim in mustering ewes and lambs is to avoid mis-mothering. <i>(1996,Boss's Story, The,140</i>)

>  <b>PERRY</b> ... any undue disturbance of the [Merino] ewes at this time will result in much mis-mothering of lambs, many of which will subsequently die or survive as `poddies' and `weeds'; ... <i>(1922,Sheep Farming in NZ,94</i>)

>  <b>COOP</b> On fat lamb farms ... the shearing muster cannot be considered a muster at all and there should be no check on mismothering at the December shearing. <i>(1950,Shearing Ewes before Lambing,20</i>)

>  <b>DUFF</b> If sight were the only method by which lambs can identify their mothers, or the chief method, mis-mothering after shearing would be a far more serious problem than it is now. <i>(Jan 2, 1951,Shepherd's Calendar,9,1961 ed.</i>)

## missionary
 
 <i>adj.</i> (Protestant) Christian

 <i>adj.</i> implying pro-Maori?

 <i>n.</i> a (usually Protestant) Christian Maori (contrast PIKOPO, a Catholic Christian; and DEVIL) spg also mihorari--> (?a mistranscription or misprin a re-borrowing of Maori <i>mihinare</i> `missionary' (in modern Maori also `Anglican': Williams, appendix) originally a maoricisation of <i>missionary.</i> a Maori Christian convert spg mihinare--> mitanere-->, mitonare

>  <b>McDONNELL</b> I certainly have never been able to discover any great difference in the conduct of the converted and the unconverted - if any difference really exists, it seems by general consent to be given in favor of the latter - indeed, the word Missionaries is used by the Europeans here only to distinguish those rogues, for whose superior rascallity we have no other sufficiently comprehensive term in our language. The fact is, they are all whether converted or unconverted, radically bad - and it is my own opinion as well as that of every one else whom I have conversed with on the subject, that no permanent good can be done among them until they are placed under a power, which shall be at once their terror, their protection, and their model. <i>(1834,Extracts From a Journal,35,1979 ed.</i>)

>  <b>WAKEFIELD</b> ... others [sc. Maoris] again said that they had turned `Mitanari', ... and that the white Mitanaris said the `Pukapuka' would be strong against the heathen. <i>(Feb 20, 1841,Journal</i>) [NOTES: 1841 Feb 20 E.J.Wakefield Journal in 1842 Heaphy NZ 58]

>  [The natives] had all evidently became `Missionaries' since I last saw them. <i>Ibid.</i> 1/23/292 [The natives] call themselves missionaries, having embraced Christianity <i>(1840,NZ Journal,1/16/199</i>)

>  <b>Markham</b> ... the Native Settlements become thicker. They are all Missionaries as they call the Christians ... Ibid. 54 I heard they were Missionaries and went up to them; ... Thirty Tattooed earnest Faces, reading and singing by the Fire with their Muskets across their Breasts, .... <i>(1834,New Zealand (various authors/titles),41,1963 ed.</i>)

>  Report says that he was a great warrior but he has now become Missionary <i>(Aug 1840,Journal of Ensign Best,233,1966 ed.</i>)

>  I asked [Raupara] if he had given up fighting intrigues and become a missionary (the common expression). <i>(1841,NZ Journal,2/32/87</i>)

## Missus
 
 <i>n.</i> constr often THE MISSUS, as a frequent contemporary male familiarity (cf THE WIFE, THE OLD WOMAN) as an often now un-contempuous reference used as much (or more) by New Zealanders as by other English speakers. In earlier days used by employees, especially on stations or farms, as a form of polite reference or address to the `boss's' wife.

Because this hunting economy and imported artifact styles coincided with the then unknown period of the extermination of the Moa in particular, Skinner, Duff and Buck revived the term Moa-hunter Maori to distinguish the first phase of ecological adaptation from the climax Classic Maori phase of the eighteenth century, with such new elements as agriculture, the fortified village, warfare, and artifact styles evolved within New Zealand. [XII] The term Moa-hunter follows the practice in culture-phase designation of coining a label of contrast. Although Moa-hunter Maoris gathered shell-fish and hunted all available birds, fish, seals and small whales, the cultural and economic phase is conveniently designated from the Moa as the largest and most spectacular game animal available during man's first adaptation to the environment and the one no longer available in the Classic Maori era. The term Moa-hunter is preferred here to the longer `Archaic Phase of New Zealand East Polynesian', too easily corrupted to `Archaic Maori', with `Archaic' meaning only `early'. <i>(1977,Moa-Hunters of NZ,xi-xii</i>)

## Moeraki Boulders
 
 <i>n.</i> (in North Otago)

>  The Moeraki boulders are an assemblage of near-perfect spheres that lie like discarded cricket balls on an east Otago beach. The largest of them span more than two metres in diameter and weigh over seven tonnes.[15] Claims have been made that the Moeraki boulders are the only rocks of their kind in the world... The truth is that concretions are common, but are usually only a few centimetres in diameter, irregular in shape and unlikely to impress... To Moeraki's Ngai Tahi residents, the boulders' origin is intertwined with the arrival of kumara from distant Hawaiki. According to Te Rungana o Moeraki, the great waka Arai-Te-Uru was wrecked during a fierce storm at Matakaea (Shag Point), just south of Moeraki. The boulders are food baskets that washed ashore after being thrown overboard to lighten the load. The Katiki concretions are said to be kumara tubers and seeds from the same wreck. <i>(Nov 2003,NZ Geographic,No. 66/12</i>)

>  Along the way she [sc. Shona McFarlane] also looks at natural art. "Sculptures like the Moeraki boulders, the Cathedral Cliffs at Gore Bay, the Oamaru stone quarry. <i>(Apr 6, 1985,Listener (New Zealand Listener),91</i>)

>  <b>SCRYMGEOUR</b> Expressing a desire to visit and visualise the famous Moeraki Boulders, the trip was made to those strange ever increasing boulders. <i>(1960,Memories of Maoriland,89</i>)

>  The Moeraki boulders are impressive, the largest two metres in diameter and weighing several tonnes. An unexplained phenomon, the boulders are believed to be 60 millions years old and lie scattered on Moeraki Beach like great soccer balls. <i>(May 20, 2003,Dominion Post,A13</i>)

>  The Ngai Tahu Trust Board has completed the purchase of the Moeraki Boulder Park complex near Oamaru. <i>(Jul 3, 1992,National Business Review,6</i>)

>  The irregularity in composition of the Moeraki boulders is so great that it would be practically impossible to manufacture cement from them of a uniform quality. <i>(Oct 4, 1879,Auckland Weekly News,15</i>)

>  <b>SELWYN</b> After breakfast we walked on to Moerangi whaling station, passing on the way, about two miles from the station some most remarkable boulders, ... which appear to have been formed not by rolling but by crystallization. <i>(Jan 10, 1844,Journal</i>) [NOTES: 1844 Jan 19 Selwyn Journal in 1851 NZ Part III (Church in the Colonies VIII) 15]

>  <b>McCLYMONT</b> [Mantell ? 1848] studied the Moeraki boulders and remarked that the whalers called them `Ninepins' and the spot itself `Vulcan's Foundry'. <i>(1940,Exploration of NZ, The</i>)

Beattie Pioneers Explore Otago 37]

It is not a fact - as popularly supposed - that the `moko' was distinctive in different families; serving, as is sometimes said, the purpose of a coat-of-arms. ## moko skink
 
 <i>n.</i> a small skink with an unusually long tail, found in coastal areas on the mainland and many islands from Bay of Plenty northwards. [<i>Oligosoma moco</i> aka Northern brown skink - see http://www.reptilepark.co.nz/nzlizard.htm.]

>  The tiny population of moko skinks (Oligosoma moco) was found at the council-run Shakespear [sic] Regional Park on the Whangaparaoa peninsula, about 30 minutes from central Auckland. ... Moko skinks were common throughout the upper North Island before Europeans settled in New Zealand but the introduction of rats and mice saw some skink populations plummet. ... Moko skinks are mostly confined to islands such as the Hauraki Gulf's Tiritiri Matangi. <i>(Sep 12, 2005,NZ Herald,A11</i>)

## Momley Peg
 
 <i>n.</i> stagknife

>  <b>SUTTON-SMITH</b> <i>Stagknife</i> (K-31), a universal game of nineteenth-century childhood, was important because it was played with the most treasured play object of all boys, the pocket knife. Although known in nearly all parts of New Zealand by the name of Stagknife, the game was also known as Bites, Jackknife, Stabknife, Knifey, Momley Peg, and Throwing the Knife. ... There were generally two players ... who each sought to deflect the point of the pocket knife from certain parts of the body by a flick of the hand in such a way that the blade would stick firmly into the ground. ... Every movement had to be done three times. [172] Typical movements were: (1) Place the open pocket knife (loose) [name of movement] [sic] on the closed knuckles of the right hand, point the knife towards the thumb, then with a quick upward flick of the hand to the left, deflect the point of the knife into the ground. <i>(1972,Folkgames of Children,171</i>)

## mongrel
 
 <i>n.</i> 1952 Feb 16 R.Gilberd notes on Mongrel Reading `Talking of Words' (Cecil Hull) p21`We might objectively and scientifically describe him, if he were ours, as a dog of mixed breeds - ... we would not be pleased if an acquaintance calls that dog a mongrel.' In town where dogs are kept largely for appearance and display `mongrel' I think has only one meaning - that a dog is of mixed breeding (with a note of disapproval or contempt). In the country mongrel has two independent meanings. (i) A dog of mixed blood. Objective - no emotional content. Indeed `pedigreed' is acquiring something of the mongrel taint, in that if a good dog has a pedigree it is mentioned with a faint note of surprise. (ii) A `no-good' whether man or animal. `He turned out mongrel' (Rod Macaulay speaking of a pedigreed mastiff that took to sheep worrying.) `When Bill brought him home I knew he'd turn out a mongrel. Sort of a cow-y look about his head.' (Walter Hull discussing a pedigreed `Totara Park' Friesian bull which proved sterile.) Talking of dogs: An `eye-dog' is a specialised type of header which works very quietly, never taking its eyes off the sheep it is trying to pen. Sheep men generally seem to think the dog hypnotises the sheep into being penned quietly. I believe that the fixity of its gaze and its complete concentration enable it to detect and counter any rebelliousness on the part of the sheep before the sheep have quite made up their minds.



 
 <i>n.</i> [[HWO distinguish from racist connotation =halfcaste, and the Australasian offensive epithet]] (See [cf. cur; mong](../C#cur;-mong))

>  <b>BEAGLEHOLE</b> Skin colour and the mixture of blood which is responsible for it [sc. high visibility in a white world] are often commented on by one Maori to another. The terms `mongrel', `black mongrel', `dago', or `black nigger', for instance, are often used by Maoris either in referring to themselves or to other Maoris in the neighbourhood. Thus one informant, in introducing herself, remarked: `I'm only a mongrel' - meaning only a mixed-blood Maori. <i>(1946,Some Modern Maoris,299</i>)

>  <b>R. GILBERD</b> `We might objectively and scientifically describe him, if he were ours, as a dog of mixed breeds - ... we would not be pleased if an acquaintance calls that dog a mongrel.' In town where dogs are kept largely for appearance and display `mongrel' I think has only one meaning - that a dog is of mixed breeding (with a note of disapproval or contempt). In the country mongrel has two independent meanings. (i) A dog of mixed blood. Objective - no emotional content. Indeed `pedigreed' is acquiring something of the mongrel taint, in that if a good dog has a pedigree it is mentioned with a faint note of surprise. (ii) A `no-good' whether man or animal. `He turned out mongrel' (Rod Macaulay speaking of a pedigreed mastiff that took to sheep worrying.) `When Bill brought him home I knew he'd turn out a mongrel. Sort of a cow-y look about his head.' (Walter Hull discussing a pedigreed `Totara Park' Friesian bull which proved sterile.) <i>(Feb 16, 1952,Personal Communication</i>) [NOTES: 1952 p.c. Feb 16 R.Gilberd notes on Mongrel Reading `Talking of Words' (Cecil Hull) p21]

>  <b>HENDERSON</b> `Some mongrel's firing at me!' cried dad, justifiably on the alert, poised to take cover and defend himself - ... <i>(1981,Exiles of Asbestos Cottage, The,129</i>)

## Moore filter
 
 <i>n.</i> [mining]

>  <b>McARA</b> <i>Moore filters</i>: Large `baskets' of canvas-covered filter-frames weighing about 16 tons and connected to a vacuum Source. First the basket was lowered by an overhead electric-crane into a tank of thickened pulp, previously treated with cyanide solution for several days. The vacuum caused a layer or cake of slime one or two inches thick to build up on the frames, while the clean solution, now laden with gold and silver, was pumped to the precipitators. When the cake reached the required thickness the basket was lifted and placed in a tank of barren cyanide solution, which was sucked through the cake removing the residual gold-bearing solution. After this the basket was placed in a `wash water' tank to remove all the solution, and then it was lifted and placed over the discharge bay; the vacuum was then released, allowing the cake to fall off (with some encouragement from a wooden scraper) into a waste sluice. [328] This process was repeated at about two-hourly intervals, with several bays working at the same time. <i>(1978,Gold Mining at Waihi (Glossary),327</i>)

## mopoke
 
 <i>n.</i> an owl

>  <b>MORRIS</b> <i>Mopoke, n.</i> aboriginal name for an Australian bird, from its note `Mopoke.' There is emphasis on the first syllable, but much more on the second. Settlers very early attempted to give an English shape and sense to this name. The attempt took two forms, ` <i>More-pork</i>,' and <i>`Mope-hawk'</i>; both forms are more than fifty years old. The r sound, however, is not present in the note of the bird, although the form <i>More-pork</i> is perhaps even more popular than the true form <i>Mope-hawk</i> seems to have been adopted through dislike of the perhaps coarser idea attaching to `pork.' The quaint spelling <i>Mawpawk</i> seems to have been adopted for a similar reason. [1827 Tasmania] <i>(1898,Austral English,301</i>)

>  <b>BELL</b> As Old Dan turned and walked towards the whare [e-acute] a `mopoke' owl that had settled on the ridge of it, and had been uttering at intervals its mournful cry, shrieked and flew away. <i>(1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,241</i>)

## morepork
 
 <i>n.</i> (figurative) a NI train

>  <b>McGILL</b> <i>Morepork, The</i> North Auckland train, from its melancholy whistle in the night. <i>(1968,Dictionary of Kiwi Slang, A,73</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> any of various marine fishes

>  [species name] marblefish .. [scientific name] <i>Aplodactylus arctidens</i> .. [other name(s)] granite trout, maori chief, morepork <i>(Jul 23, 1986,Codes for Species in NZ Waters</i>)

>  <b>SORENSON</b> <i>COD, ROCK </i>(a) Scientific name: <i>Lotella rhacinus</i>. (b) Suggested commercial name[s]: Rock Cod; Kelp Cod. (c) Other common names: Parrotfish; Soldiers, Kelp, Kelpies, Moreporks, Marblefish, Maori Chief, Wrasse, Bourbon, Guffy, Cloudy Bay Cod, Rasp. <i>(1970,Nomenclature of NZ Fish,18</i>)

## Moriori myth
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>SORRENSON</b> Then in 1937 he published an essay called `The Maruiwi myth'. This was concerned largely with the first part of the legend of the coming of the Maori - `that the first Polynesian settlers who arrived with Toi ... found the North Island - possibly both islands - inhabited by a non-Polynesian race, known as Maruiwi or Mouriuri, whom they subsequently exterminated; a small remnant alone escaping to colonize the Chatham Islands'. <i>(1979,Maori Origins and Migrations,53</i>) [NOTES: 1979 Sorrenson Maori Origins and Migrations 53 quoting 1937 H.W.Williams J.P.S. 46/105-122]

>  <b>WISNIOWSKI</b> This passage embodies an early version of what has become known as the `Moriori myth'. Except for the name Moriori, which was borrowed from the Chatham Islands and applied by 1880 to supposed pre-Maori inhabitants of New Zealand, the theory is all here in a book published in 1877, based on material collected in the mid-1860s. A black-skinned, curly-headed people with timid dispositions, presumably negroid or Melanesian, were supposed to have been found in possession of New Zealand by the first Polynesian settlers and exterminated by them except for a few with whom they intermarried, so that their racial traits appeared from time to time among the Maoris. <i>(1877,Tikera,301</i>) [NOTES: 1972 ed. note in 1877 WISNIOWSKI Tikera (trans. Podstolski 1972) 301]

## mountain
 
 <i>adj.</i> as a distinguishing epithet with names of plants often merely translates the specific <i>alpinus, montana</i>, etc. rather than originating in a general observation expressing itself in a given vernacular descriptive term: e.g. <i>Phyllocladus alpinus,</i> mountain toa toa -->a. chiefly botanical (rather than popular) uses include MOUNTAIN -BUTTERCUP, -COTTONWOOD, -FOXGLOVE, -HOLLY, -LANCEWOOD, -PALM, -PIRIPIRI, -TREE-DAISY, -TWITCH, WINEBERRY; b. popular (often local) uses distinguishing alpine or sub-alpine species include: (though often the vernacular name may have originally been botanically given.) e.g. MOUNTAIN-BEECH, MOUNTAIN-PINE, MOUNTAIN-RIBBONWOOD. (see Andersen Popular Names of NZ Plants Tr NZI; and 1933 Acland.) -->for animals see DUCK, KIWI, MINNOW, PARROT, TROUT -->as a distinguishing epithet in the names of plants see AKEAKE, ASTELIA, ASTER, BEECH; BEECH, SOUTHERN; BIRCH, BLADDERWORT, BUTTERCUP; BUTTERCUP, YELLOW; CABBAGE-TREE, CASSINIA, CEDAR; PINE, CELERY; CLUB-MOSS, COTTONWOOD, COTULA, CURRANT, DAISY, DANTHONIA, EVERLASTING; FERN, FILMY; FERN, SHIELDFERN; FERN TREE-FERN; FERN UMBRELLA; FLAX, FORGET-ME-NOT, FOXGLOVE, GENTIAN, GRASS, OAT-GRASS; GRASS, TWITCH; HOLLY, HYPERICUM, IVY-TREE, KOROKIO, LANCEWOOD, LILY, MARGUERITE, MOP, MUSK, MYRRH, PALM, PANAX, PINE; PINE, CELERY; PIRIPIRI, PRIMULA, RATA, RIBBONWOOD, RIMU, SEDGE, SNOWBERRY; TAUHINU, TAWHEOWHEO, TOATOA, TOETOE, TOTARA, TREE-DAISY; TUSSOCK-GRASS; TUTU UNCINIA, VIOLET, WILLOW-HERB, WINEBERRY

## mountain beech
 
 <i>n.</i> Nothofagus solandri (var. cliffortioides), a beech common in drier subalpine forest.

>  <b>LAING & BLACKWELL</b> <i>(1906,Plants of NZ</i>) [NOTES: (And)]

>  Cockayne Botanical Survey Tongariro National Park <i>(1908,AJHR</i>) [NOTES: (And) [N. clif]]

>  <i>(1909,AJHR,C-11</i>) [NOTES: (And) [N. clif] Turner Botanical Examination Higher Waimarino]

>  <i>Nothofagus cliffortioides</i>, TAWHAI-RAURIKI (cf BIRCH) perhaps mainly a scientific or trade term <i>(1925,Duncan & Davies' Catalogue</i>) [NOTES: also in 1917 edition (And) [N. cliff],]

>  <b>LAING & BLACKWELL</b> <i>N. Cliffortioides (The Cliffortia-like Beech)</i> ... The <i>Mountain beech. </i> <i>(1940,Plants of NZ,140</i>)

>  <b>MASTERS</b> The track, for most of the way, leads along the crest of a main ridge, and passes, for several miles, through an area of native mountain beech forest. <i>(1960,Back-Country Tales,77</i>)

>  <i>Fagus cliffortioides.</i> - This tree much resembles <i>F. Solandri</i>, but it is found generally only at high altitudes; it is unlikely to be of much value as a timber, though it is of great use to retard soil-erosion. The most suitable name for it is `mountain-beech.' <i>(1918,NZ Journal of Science & Technology,1/308</i>) [NOTES: (E. Phillips Turner)]

>  <b>CHEESEMAN</b> <i>F. Cliffortioides, Hook.f</i>. ... A small tree, usually from 20 ft. to 40 ft. high ... Mountain districts ... <i>Tawhai-rauriki; Mountain Beech or Birch. </i> <i>(1906,Manual NZ Flora,643</i>)

>  <i>(1916,TrNZI,48</i>) [NOTES: (And)]

>  <b>MARK & ADAMS</b> Usually it is silver beech with small toothed leaves but in the drier areas, especially Canterbury, eastern Nelson and Marlborough in the South Island and on the highly porous soils of the volcanic plateau in the North Island, silver beech [<i>Nothofagus solandri </i>var. <i>cliffortioides</i>] is replaced by mountain beech with small, smoothed-edged leaves. <i>(1973,NZ Alpine Plants,10,1979 ed.</i>)

>  <b>DENDY</b> As we ascend the character of the vegetation changes, the mountain beech [fn <i>Fagus cliffortioides.</i>] replaces that of lower altitudes, and the undergrowth consists largely of the alpine celery pine [fn <i>Phyllocladus alpinus</i>.], an almost unique member of the order <i>Coniferae</i>, with the [188] customary needle-like leaves replaced by flattened leaf-like branches, ... <i>(1900,Canterbury Old & New,186, 188</i>)

>  <b>KIRK</b> [N. cliff] <i>(1889,Forest Flora</i>) [NOTES: And)]

>  English Name Native name Botanical Name Mountain Beech .. Fagus Cliffortioides <i>(1889,Catalogue, Canterbury Court Exhibition,35</i>)

>  <i>(1890,PWD Catalogue of Timbers,9</i>)

>  Mr. Enys' house ... is 2,500 feet above the sea, and is beautifully situated in a clump of Mountain Beech (<i>Fagus cliffortioides</i>) ... <i>(1891,NZ Journal of Science,1/202</i>)

>  <b>HUDSON</b> [N. cliff] <i>(1898,NZ Moths & Butterflies</i>) [NOTES: (And)]

>  <b>MOORE & IRWIN</b> <i>NOTHOFAGUS SOLANDRI </i>variety <i>CLIFFORTIOIDES. Mountain beech, widespread from East Cape southwards, is particularly abundant on poor mountain soils ... </i> <i>(1978,Oxford Book of NZ Plants,80</i>)

>  <b>DENDY</b> <i>(1900,Canterbury Old & New,186, 188</i>)

>  <i>mountain beech n, Austral & NewZeal </i>: a tree of the genus <i>Nothofagus </i> <i>(1961,Merriam-Webster Third International,1477</i>)

>  <b>McLINTOCK</b> Beech ... Mountain .. tawhairauriki <i>Nothofagus cliffortioides </i> <i>(1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,3/710</i>)

>  <b>DENNIS</b> Mountain beech (<i>N. solandri var. cliffortioides</i>) descends to river terraces ... <i>(1981,Paparoas Guide,159</i>)

>  [Ruahines] [We] take the track into splendid kaikawaka (pahautea) and mountain beech bush <i>(1978,Manawatu Tramping Club Jubilee,99</i>)

## mudfish
 
 <i>n.</i> the general name for the varieties of New Zealand fish which can live in mud or damp surroundings

>  The fish is the New Zealand mud-fish (Neochanna apoda). It is usually found in clay, in places which are overflowed by rivers when they are in flood. <i>(Sep 25, 1912,Otago Witness,76</i>)

>  <b>HUTTON</b> 97. NEOCHANNA APODA. Gunth. Mud Fish. <i>(1872,Fishes,61</i>)

>  <b>BULLER</b> ... he produced a dish of water containing some `mudfish' which [the Bittern] instantly ... devoured. This singular fish (named by Dr. Gu[dieresis]nther <i>Neochanna apoda</i>) is very common in the Hokitika district, being found in all the creeks and surface-ponds in the woods ...On the pools becoming dry these mudfish burrow into the moist soil or clay, ... remaining there for an indefinite time, or until the return of the rainy weather rendered their pools habitable again. <i>(1873,Birds of New Zealand,237</i>)

>  <b>SHERRIN</b> <i>Neochanna apoda</i> Gunther Mud-fish <i>(1886,Handbook Fishes of NZ,305</i>)

Gunther says <i>Neochanna</i> is a `degraded form of Galaxias [see <i>Mountain-Trout</i>], from which it differs by the absence of ventral fins. This fish has hitherto been found only in burrows which it excavates in clay or consolidated mud, at a distance from water.' <i>(1898,Austral English,305</i>)

>  <b>DRUMMOND & HUTTON</b> The mudfish is found in clay or mud, several feet below the surface,... <i>(1902,Nature in NZ,76</i>)

>  <b>WILLIAMS</b> <i>Hauhau </i>(i) n Neochanna apoda, <i>mud-fish = waikaka. </i> <i>(1957,Dictionary of the Maori Language,39</i>)

## muka
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a strip of flax fibre. [ORIGIN: Maori]

>  <b>TAIT</b> The dressing of the flax (muka) was continued when Mr Flay took up the land. <i>(1956,Farms & Stations of NZ Vol I,65</i>)

>  <b>BOSWELL</b> Plaited whips, complete with handle, leather thong and muka lash. Muka is the Maori name for the flax fibre after the green has been scraped from the fibrous skeleton <i>(1960,Ernie and the Rest of Us,143</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> edible part of nikau

>  <b>WILLIAMS</b> . . .at the bottom of the leafs [of the nikau], a fruit or white substance is found, out of which grows the leafs. This substance is called by the natives `Pito' (pronounced peetaw [pitau]). The middle is in seperate [sic] layers called `Muka' from its resemblance to the flax, eaten by the natives, ... <i>(1844,NZ Journal,108,1956 ed.</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> the prepared fibre of New Zealand flax [ORIGIN: Maori]

>  <b>POLACK</b> The flax (<i>korari</i>,) forming the dresses is of two or [176] three kinds; the most coarse, called muka, is employed for working the common garment (<i>kakaou</i>[a1-acute] <i>maori</i>[a-acute].) This flax is also made use of for laying up ropes, lines, &c. The superior dress called Kaitaka[a2-a3-acute], is made from silken flax, <i>(hunga hunga</i>[as-acute].) <i>(1840,Manners & Customs of the NZers,1/175</i>)

>  Muka of the natives, as the dressed fibre of the Harakeke, or Flax Plant) <i>(1869,TrNZI,1/III/48</i>) [NOTES: (Colenso Botany North Isd)]

>  The Korari is the name of the flower stalk, often, but wrongly, used as the name of the plant. The edible root is the Aruhe. The word `Muka' is commonly applied to the dressed fibre; it is the correct name for the inner leaves. Cleared bush-land is suitable for the cultivation of the flax plant, and even swamp-land is improved by drainage. In the various flax swamps near nelson ...the finest plants grow upon the soil that has been thrown out of the ditch ... <i>(1870,TrNZI,2/117</i>) [NOTES: (Heaphy NZ Flax)]

>  The renovation of `Rangiatea' is a much bigger undertaking. ... The wall tukutuku are about 16 feet high while in the gables they run up to 30 feet. The old fellows must have put in a lot of thought to piece together such lengths against a real kakaho backing, with muka [ed fn: Prepared flax] binding to keep the whole in position. To keep the horizontals from sagging with the sheer weight of the material the muka binding was passed through holes bored into the edges of the poupou - an adaption of the rauawa technique. <i>(Mar 17, 1931,Na To Hoa Aroha,2/128,1987 ed.</i>) [NOTES: (Ngata)]

>  Aesthetically beautiful and entirely natural, the stunning Hapene range is exclusively designed and produced in Fielding, and uses a patented method to release the muka, or fibre, within the leaf. <i>(Sep 2005,Air New Zealand inflight magazine,12</i>) [NOTES: -]

>  <i>muka</i>, prepared fibre of flax (harakeke). <i>(1946,Journal of the Polynesian Society,55/154</i>) [NOTES: Andersen Maori Words in English]

>  <b>REED</b> [Mrs Brown recounts:] At other times we would sit down amongst some flax bushes, and make `muka' for whip-lashes. <i>(1953,Story of the Kauri, The,141</i>)

>  <b>BOSWELL</b> ... beautiful, compactly plaited whips complete with handle, leather thong and muka lash. Muka is the Maori name for the flax fibre after the green has been scraped from the fibrous skeleton ... <i>(1960,Ernie and the Rest of Us,143</i>)

>  <b>HULME</b> I was playing, making knots in the muka in the sun/ and I dropped the tangle, forgot it/ <i>(1982,Moeraki Conversations,16</i>) [NOTES: Hulme The Silences Between]

>  <b>KEENE</b> <i>muka</i>: prepared fibre of flax. <i>(1963,O Te Raki,193</i>)

>  <b>SAVAGE</b> Mooca .. Thread, cord, rope. <i>(1807,New Zealand (various authors/titles),76</i>)

>  <b>NICHOLAS</b> Flax Moka <i>(1817,New Zealand (various authors/titles),2/336</i>)

>  <b>MARSDEN</b> You will send the <i>Active</i> full of moca (muka), potatoes, limes, mats, fish, and nets. <i>(Mar 9, 1814,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1814 Mar 9 Marsden in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 58]

>  <b>MARSDEN</b> The women employ part of their time in making kakkahows (kakahu), <i>mats, moka</i> (muka), <i>etc.,</i> ... <i>(Jun 25, 1814,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1814 July 25 Kendall in Elder Marsden's Lieutenants (1934) 67]

>  <b>CRAIK</b> In this prepared state it is ... called mooka ... <i>(1830,New Zealanders, The,181</i>)

>  <b>DIEFFENBACH</b> Muka - flax prepared <i>(1843,Travels in NZ,2/374</i>)

>  a mat of muka flax is then made. It is then filled with berries and is placed in a hangi (oven) underground on heated stones. <i>(1844,NZ Journal,99,1956 ed.</i>)

>  <b>HOOKER</b> Muka, <i>W.Mantell.</i> Dressed fibre of <i>Phormium tenax. </i> <i>(1867,Handbook NZ Flora (List of Names),766</i>)

>  <b>BAINES</b> He said that the natives all the country round about would bring me for sale a great amount of `muka' scraped flax - ... and wheat without <i>(1874,Edward Crewe,116</i>)

>  <b>TREGEAR</b> The fibre (<i>muka</i>) was then steeped for three or four days in running water, taken out and pounded with a stone beater. <i>Ibid.</i> 258 Sometimes the chisel was not dipped into the pigment but a wad of scraped flax (<i>muka</i>) with the pigment smeared thereon was drawn over the wound ... <i>(1904,Maori Race, The,222</i>)

>  <b>PINFOLD</b> As the blood oozes from the wound, it is dexterously wiped away with the `muka', a small bunch of finely prepared flax. <i>(1930,Fifty Years In Maoriland,25</i>)

>  <b>BUCK</b> <i>(1949,Coming of the Maori, The,3/351</i>)

>  <b>COLLINS</b> E-mu-ka, <i>The flax plant when dressed. </i> <i>(1804,English Colony in NSW,561</i>)

>  <b>LINDSAY</b> In Otago the general name of the [flax] plant, as a whole, is `Korari,' - or as metamorphosed by the settler, pronounced and spelt `Kouradi,' [a-macron] or `Coradi' [a-macron]. The same term is applied in the North Island equally to the whole plant, and to the dried flower-stem when cut for rafts or other purposes; or exclusively to the flower-stalk. In the North [83] Island, the Flax-plant is also known as `Harakeke,' or `Herekiakia,' - its usual name there. ... The lower part of the flower-stem is `Kaikaha;' the outer part of the leaf `Parakoka;' [a1, o-macron] the refuse of the leaf `Hunga-hunga;' the flax, dressed or not, or scraped fibre, manufactured from the leaf, `Whitau,' or `Muka.' <i>(1868,Contributions to NZ Botany,82</i>)

## Muldoonism
 
 <i>n.</i> (Politics) the political (and economic) style of the National Government Prime Minister (Sir) Robert Mulddon (19 - to 1984) [ORIGIN: eponym]

>  Muldoonism is in the language and in the history, but there is a touch of tragedy listening to a man who refused to back down. <i>(Sep 16, 2000,Listener (New Zealand Listener),63</i>)

>  Kerr said the PM.s call for his sacking "reminds one of Muldoonism." <i>(Dec 17, 2000,Sunday Star Times,C3</i>)

>  The epithet `Muldoonism', used by politicians, schoolchildren and businessmen alike, has become a familiar word in the Kiwi vocabulary. <i>(Feb 14, 1973,Dominion,7/6</i>)

>  They [cool TV newsreaders] were symbols of a benign paternalism that paraded the daily doses of murder, mayhem and Muldoonism past us and wordlessly reassured us: `There, there, it won't really hurt you. ...' Whatever did happen to that old comfortable world; has it all been Rogernomicised out of existence? Happily no. What we used to call social justice and now term wimpishness still lives. <i>(Nov 7, 1986,National Business Review,11</i>)

>  Under his tutelage New Zealand learned to live beyond its means as it had never done before, to such an extent that nobody seems to know quite how large its total foreign debt has become, except that it is certainly huge and may be a per capita world record. Its welfare state, which has often been held up as an example to the world, was allowed to swell as its traditional and all-important agricultural markets shrank. As the budget deficit widened, Sir Robert became an apparently immovable fixture, the political Mr Micawber of the southern hemisphere. Now the voters have awoken to the unreal nature of what long since became known to them as `Muldoonism', its creator and chief exponent could not bring himself to accept his stinging defeat, like many another unseated authoritarian before him. <i>(Jul 22, 1984,Guardian Weekly, The</i>)

>  <i>The Rose</i> was topical, they said, because it dealt with Muldoonism at its height. ... The play was just as much a comment on the political reactions of New Zealanders as it was about Muldoonism. For once, [Roger] Hall was creating and taking sides. <i>(Aug 9, 1986,Listener (New Zealand Listener),39</i>)

>  Laidlaw says he was a traitor - to Muldoonism, not to his country. <i>(Dec 4, 1989,Listener (New Zealand Listener),5</i>)

>  In the meantime the word `strong' needs urgently to be redefined. For the majority of men - and increasing number of women - it is at present simply Muldoonism brought into the sphere of personal and professional relations. Deny your most [119] tender feelings, destroy those who reveal themselves as vulnerable or sensitive, put down the opposition like dogs, polarise everybody in sight, create plausible scapegoats, ... and hate ... with all the venom you can muster. <i>(Jan 1987,Metro,118</i>)

>  Meurant simply seized on probably the only appealing aspect of Muldoonism these days for the born-again Nats, the former prime minister's cheery ability to throw ... allegations of treason ... <i>(Oct 8, 1987,National Business Review,10</i>)

>  Remember the Belgian millionaire who arrived here ... when the country was firmly in the grip of Muldoonism? <i>(Nov 13, 1988,Sunday Star Times,A15</i>)

>  On Tuesday he likened former leader Nee Wyn's socialism as a `classic case of Muldoonism'. Those policies collapsed the country, leaving it one of the least developed countries in Asia. <i>(Jul 31, 1988,Sunday Star (Auckland),A4</i>)

>  But there they are complaining bitterly about the way the still waters of Government and the dribblings of Muldoonism are wetting their feet. <i>(Jul 24, 1970,Dominion,10d</i>)

>  Muldoonism, to its followers and its critic, meant Think Big and Intervention. <i>(Aug 5, 1992,Evening Post,7</i>)

>  Mr Quigley's sacking did much to coalesce the forces building up against "Muldoonism". <i>(Aug 6, 1992,Dominion,11</i>)

>  It was a long and strange journey for New Zealand into Muldoonism. <i>(Aug 9, 1992,Dominion Sunday Times,10</i>)

>  Such an article (Allan, 1952) of especial interest in this era of "Muldoonism" - a time when the role of the University in New Zealand and the subjects taught threin is [sic] under scrutiny - appeared in "Canta", the newspaper of the Students' Association of Canterbury University College (as it then was called), a response to a questionnaire sent to heads of departments to ascertain their views on the role of the particular subjects in the university curriculum and as a guidance to students trying to "justify their presence". <i>(May 1971,Geological Society of NZ Newsletter,30/11</i>)

>  Critics of Finance Minister Michael Cullen's moves to block the foreign takeover of Auckland Airport have accused him of Muldoonism .. At times like this, would a dash of Muldoonism be so bad? <i>(Mar 12, 2008,NZ Herald,A7</i>)

>  Used badly, it could trigger incipient Muldoonism among Labour's leaders. <i>(Jun 16, 2002,Sunday Star Times,E2</i>)

## mullein

If a man allowed one of his boy children to get hurt, the tribe would <i>muru</i> the father for the [140] loss ... since the boy probably would have been a future warrior. ... <i>Ibid.</i> 141 Perhaps `damages' rather than `plunder' is the best translation of <i>muru</i>. <i>(1904,Maori Race, The,139</i>)

>  <b>POWELL</b> MUSSEL'S BEARD (<i>Sertularia bispinosa</i>). A yellowish-brown, fine, hair-like mass which grows commonly amongst low tidal sea-weeds, in rock pools and especially upon the shells of living mussels. <i>(1947,Native Animals of NZ,6</i>)

## muster
 
 <i>n.</i> an assembly of intending participants

>  [public notice] PAROA NETBALL MUSTER... <i>(Mar 3, 2006,Whakatane Beacon,23</i>)

>  [heading] <b>College Old Boys, R.F.C. Levin MUSTER</b> <i>(Dec 14, 2005,Horowhenua-Kapiti Chronicle,11</i>)

>  WAIOHAU SOFTBALL CLUB INC AGM & MUSTER <i>(Aug 26, 2005,Whakatane Beacon,40</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a round-up of livestock, especially sheep for shearing, etc. musterer, a person who musters sheep, etc. [Latin monstrare to show] [(The word seems to have been introduced to Canterbury) Acland (1933) notes the following musters on high-country stations. -->So far as I know the usual ones are (beginning in the spring): <i>the cutting and tailing muster; shearing</i> muster; <i>straggle</i> muster (in the old days the shorn sheep were always turned not before the country .us;was straggled, <i>so that they would lead the woolies in); dipping or wearing </i>m.; <i>straggle </i>again; then <i>scratch</i> m. or <i>`lock-over' </i>to get the last of the sheep off the summer country before winter. This last is an undress sort of muster, the men catching what stragglers they can in the basins. There are always other partical musters of the flock; e.g., ewes to ram, or eye-slipping of hoggets.] (See [also tailing muster](../A#also-tailing-muster))

>  It knocks the sheep about too much to do other than have one principal muster for docking. <i>(Oct 16, 1912,Otago Witness,16</i>)

>  <b>ELWELL</b> The mode of mustering adopted by Ernest was this. .... He made a separate muster of each part [of the run] <i>(1878,Boy Colonists,172</i>)

>  <b>ELWELL</b> The mode of mustering adopted by Ernest was this. .... He made a separate muster of each part [of the run] <i>(1878,Boy Colonists,172</i>)

>  <b>KIERNAN</b> Finlayson went to Arapawanui to try and get Atta for the muster. <i>(Jan 13, 1879,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1879 Jan 13 T.C. Kiernan Diary in 1921 Guthrie-Smith Tutira 123]

>  2404 sheep to be accounted for, which is either a most fearful number of deaths or the worst muster ever yet made. <i>(Dec 4, 1879,Chudleigh Diary,282,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>BELL</b> It was expected that a few of Morton's sheep might have got through the dividing fence since the last muster, ... <i>(1899,In the Shadow of the Bush,79</i>)

>  <i>Muster</i>.-A city correspondent asks for the names of the various musters on high country stations. So far as I know the usual ones are (beginning in spring): the cutting and tailing <i>m.</i>; shearing <i>m.</i>; straggle <i>m.</i>(in old days the shorn sheep were always turned out before the country was straggled, so that they would lead the woolies in); dipping or weaning <i>m.</i> (to wean the lambs and dip the ewes); fall (or autumn) m.; straggle again; then scratch <i>m.</i> or `look over' to get the last of the sheep off the summer country before winter. This last is an undress sort of <i>m.</i>, the men catching what stragglers they can in the basins. There are always other partial <i>ms</i>. of the flock; <i>e.g.</i>, ewes to ram or eye clipping of hoggets. <i>(Jan 27, 1934,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Gloss. additions]

>  <b>REVANS</b> I am not yet confident of the mode in which flock and stock musters will be dealt with by the natives <i>(1841,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1841 Revans to Chapman 90]

>  <b>ACLAND</b> The great difficulty in cleaning the sheep consists ... in getting a clean muster; ... <i>(1858,Notes on Sheepfarming in NZ,12</i>)

>  <b>DUPPA</b> Make a second clean muster of stragglers <i>(1860,Letter</i>) [NOTES: 1860 Duppa September in 1949 Crawford Sheep and Sheepmen 47]

>  <b>KENNAWAY</b> As far as <i>I'm </i>concerned, I'm here,/ And camping out upon a muster./ <i>(1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,95</i>)

>  <b>WEKEY</b> ... the difficulties of shepherding here must always be great, ...; a full muster at shearing time is never obtained, as the heights ... afford on occasion a retreat to the sheep, ... The conjecture is, that he had been endeavoring [sic] to collect some of the stragglers of his flock, and ... had missed either his hold or footing ... <i>(1862,Otago As It Is,11</i>)

>  ... a full muster at shearing time is never obtained - the heights which to most animals would be a wall and a fence, afford on occasion a retreat to the sheep, ... <i>(Aug 23, 1862,Otago Witness,6</i>)

>  Made the first muster today, we yarded some 3000 sheep. <i>(Oct 12, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,106,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>BARKER</b> It is impossible to estimate our loss until the grand muster at shearing, but we may set it down at half our flock ... <i>(1867,Station Life in NZ,173,1870 ed.</i>)

>  <b>TINNE</b> It is customary to invite all your neighbour to your `muster' . <i>Ibid.</i> 38 It is customary to invite all the neighbours to your `muster,' as they can then pick out their missing sheep which have strayed from the adjoining runs. As they complete each flock, it is turned over to a shepherd, who would drive it off with the aid of his dogs to a beat, possibly ten or twenty miles distant ... <i>(1873,Wonderland of the Antipodes,37</i>)

>  <b>CAIRD</b> My sheep met a shepherd coming down and joined in with the result of his muster. <i>(1874,Sheepfarm,20</i>)

>  <b>KENNAWAY</b> ... to these five were added two shepherds and a stockman from one station ... come over from front runs to attend a general muster of our sheep and cattle. <i>(1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,143</i>)

>  <b>MEREDITH</b> As the sheep are slightly infected with scab we have to dip them periodically to eradicate ... the parasite; but it is a hard job because, on these fern-clad [Wairarapa] runs, it is almost impossible to get an absolutely clean muster of the sheep. <i>(1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,87,1935 ed.</i>)

>  <b>SHARPE</b> ... How long would we spend on the actual muster? <i>(1966,Fiordland Muster,54</i>)

>  <i>muster n.</i> see bangtail muster. <i>(1966,NZ Contemp. Dict. Suppl. (Whitcombe's),620</i>)

>  <i>muster ... 4. Austral. & N.Z.</i> to round up (stock). <i>7. Austral. & N.Z</i>. the act of rounding up stock. <i>(1982,Collins Concise English Dictionary,743</i>) [NOTES: [1986 NZPOD 496; 1985 Collins NZ Compact Dict. 321]]

 <i>n.</i> [1933 Acland a temporary shepherd engaged for mustering. The musterers, however, usually include the permanent shepherds and cadets as well.]

>  ... George left school at 14 to fulfil his dream of becoming a high-country musterer. <i>(Mar 2005,NZ Geographic,72/25</i>)

>  All the musterers [sic] dogs have come home and Abner came home for some food. ... It always rains at mustering. . <i>(Dec 19, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,114,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>BARKER</b> Tired musterers sit down under the shadow of a great rock .... and have a ten-minutes `spell' and half a pipe. <i>(1872,Christmas Cake in Four Quarters,Ch.. I</i>)

>  <b>ELWELL</b> ...musterers would start again... <i>(1878,Boy Colonists,174</i>)

>  <b>KIERNAN</b> Musterers started this evening. <i>(Feb 11, 1879,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1879 Feb 11 T.C. Kiernan Diary in 1921 Guthrie-Smith Tutira 126]

>  <b>KIERNAN</b> Musterers started this evening. <i>(Feb 11, 1879,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1879 Feb 11 T.C. Kiernan Diary in 1921 Guthrie-Smith Tutira 126]

>  <b>SWANTON</b> To accomplish this [muster] on large `runs', additional hands called `musterers' have to be engaged. <i>(1892,Notes on NZ,97</i>)

>  <b>BURDON</b> But still [sc. after the fencing of runs] at certain times of the year sheep had to be got in ... and at these times shepherds were required. Thus the work [of shepherds], from being permanent, became seasonal, and gangs of men would go from station to station as they were wanted, ... They were called musterers. <i>(1938,High Country,105</i>)

>  I would include among New Zealand English words: <i>musterer</i>: shepherd <i>(May 6, 1952,VUC First Year English Class</i>)

>  Bob was a musterer and so spent much of his working life away from home. <i>(May 1994,NZ Historic Places,47/31</i>)

>  <b>McCASKILL</b> I have instructed my new manager..to cooperate with you as to working the two stations with one staff of musterers, shearers and shed hands, whereby we can save a lot of money. <i>(1969,Molesworth,55</i>) [NOTES: Quoted from Acton-Adams c1885]

>  You might easily have become the best fly-musterer in that part of the world. <i>(Aug 31, 1942,NZEF Times,II/62 : 5</i>)

>  They [sc. musterers] can stand days of shingle sidling.. and be quizzical through it all. <i>(Apr 1945,NZ Geographer,I : 27</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> It was pretty easy for a musterer, thirsting for a hair of the dog that bit him, to miss that turn-off. <i> Ibid.</i> 85 Normally these musterers are inclined to jib at milking cows but there was no objection this time - cow-spanking would be a lot easier than that fencing job. <i>(1966,Boss's Story, The,50</i>)

>  The musterers on this place are all of the right sort. <i>(Dec 8, 1911,Maoriland Worker,14</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a gatherer of stock in to a single location on a farm or station.

>  <b>CHUDLEIGH</b> All the musterers dogs have come home. <i>(Dec 19, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,114</i>) [NOTES: (1950)]

>  <b>SWANTON</b> To accomplish this on large 'runs', additional hands called 'musterers' have to be engaged. <i>(1892,Notes on NZ,97</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> On the average station, the mustering gang consists of the "Boss," a head shepherd - a permanent station employee - and four to six musterers. <i>(1947,Wayleggo,13</i>)



## musterer's stick
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a strong hillpole or hillstick used in high-country mustering [usually made from manuka or mingimingi] [[See introduction to Woodhouse Farm and Station Verse]]

>  <b>McCASKILL</b> A musterer's stick would then be pushed through the hamstrings and the carcase lifted. ... Apart from his dogs the musterer's most used piece of equipment was his hill stick, a six-foot piece of manuka with a ferrule fitted at the end to reduce wear. <i>(1969,Molesworth,101</i>)

>  <b>MCLEOD</b> A musterer's stick, next to his dogs and boots, is his most valuable possession. <i>(1970,Many a Glorious Morning,85</i>)

>  <b>MCRAE</b> The musterer's stick is known as a pole or hillstick or hillpole. <i>(1998,On the Run,30</i>)



## musterers' hut
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) an isolated, basic whare or shelter used by musterers. [also musterer's hut]

>  My daughter and I in a musterer's hut, the grand icy alpine night settling on the mountains around our ears. <i>(Jun 2001,NZ Geographic,52/44</i>)

>  Bush Hut, one of the 14 musterers' huts on Glenaray station. <i>(Oct 16, 1950,NZ Journal of Agriculture,346</i>)

>  <b>MCLEOD</b> That was his first night in a musterers' hut. <i>(1954,On the Hill,30</i>)

>  <b>PORTER</b> Once he had packed out to a musterers' hut .. and lay down on the bunk to rest. <i>(1970,Under the Nor'West Arch,78</i>)

>  <b>PICKERING</b> By including the old tin musterers' huts, the dog-kennel bivouacs .. accommodation of some sort has now run up to almost a thousand sites in the hills. <i>(1988,Hills, The,7</i>)

>  <b>OWEN & PERKINS</b> The storm forced the party down the Godley Glacier and valley to a musterers' hut for a better night. <i>(1958,Speaking for Ourselves,92</i>)



## mustering
 
 <i>n.</i> [1860 September Duppa (1949 Crawford 47) ... collect stragglers for a second mustering]

>  <b>MONEY</b> He was one of the owners of Tarndale, the largest cattle-station in the country, and the next day I passed the homestead, and saw a party of his hands preparing for a mustering expedition. <i>(1871,Knocking About in NZ,85</i>)

>  <b>ELWELL</b> In mustering times, Ernest used to set some of the huge boulders on the sides of [the] cliffs rolling, and they make quite a roaring noise ... This noise startled the sheep .... which always made upwards. <i>(1878,Boy Colonists,169</i>)

>  Piripi ... made an attempt to get the mustering wages raised so I told them to go home and started without them. <i>(Dec 1, 1887,Chudleigh Diary,358,1950 ed.</i>)

>  The result ... was that at nearly every mustering these short-winded sheep used to be left behind ... <i>(1891,NZ Journal of Science,1/173</i>)

>  <b>SCRYMGEOUR</b> Long mustering days, mostly on foot, where in the winter of '86, a cart drawn by two horses, crossed the Waitaki on the ice. <i>(1960,Memories of Maoriland,8</i>)

>  We had as usual the hardest day's mustering today on the Isolated Hills ... <i>(Oct 25, 1865,Chudleigh Diary,202,1950 ed.</i>)

>  <b>WILSON</b> To show how different the mustering is in this country, out of 70,000 sheep Campbell ... was over 15,000 short at shearing and has to muster several different times before he can get all the stragglers in. <i>(Feb 2, 1873,Diary</i>) [NOTES: 1873 Feb 2 G.M.Wilson Diary in 1973 Wierzbicka Wilson Family 164]

>  <b>KENNAWAY</b> Our run was covered with scattered sheep which it was impossible to move by weeks of mustering; ... <i>(1874,Crusts: a settler's fare due south,141</i>)

>  <b>MEREDITH</b> I have bought a very good collie, and he assists in the mustering. <i>(1875,Adventuring in Maoriland in the Seventies,87,1935 ed.</i>)

>  <b>ELWELL</b> The mode of mustering adopted by Ernest was this ... He made a separate muster of each part [of the run] <i>(1878,Boy Colonists,172</i>)

>  <b>JOLLIE</b> ... sheep mustering <i>(1879,Reminiscences,49</i>)

>  <b>McLEOD</b> As the flocks increased, this question of getting the sheep in became a big one - they called it mustering. <i>(1951,High Country,5</i>)



 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) the gathering in and movement of farm stock.

>  All the musterers dogs here come home and Abner came home for some food. ... It always rains at mustering. <i>(Dec 19, 1863,Chudleigh Diary,114,1950 ed.</i>)

>  Charlie came down in evening to arrange about mustering. <i>(Jan 17, 1864,Haldon Station Diary,250</i>) [NOTES: in Vance (1965) High Endeavour]

>  <b>BATHGATE</b> Life on a sheep station is rather a dull one. There are periodical 'musterings' and other duties to be attended to ... <i>(1874,Colonial Experiences,206</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Open tussock country running up to the shingle slopes of the Old Man Range, it proved to be comparatively simple mustering. <i>(1947,Wayleggo,25</i>)

>  <b>KERR</b> Suppose I'd better tell you what mustering is, because there's going to be a fair bit of it. <i>(2000,High Times in the High Country,44</i>)



## mustering beat
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a particular area allotted to a musterer as his responsibility in a muster [usually specified as the top beat, middle beat and bottom beat.]

>  <b>GORDON</b> Like a policeman a musterer treads a beat - the better the man, the higher the beat. <i>(1983,Other Side of Farming, The,1</i>)

>  <b>HALL</b> She was on holiday with her mother and she accompanied me on a mustering beat. <i>(1987,Shepherd's Year,  A,79</i>)



## mustering billy
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a tapered tin utensil with a broad base and narrow neck.

>  <b>STACEY</b> mustering billy - a tapered tin utensil with a broad base and a narrow neck in which the tin cup fits acting as a lid. <i>(1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,165</i>)

>  <b>McLEOD</b> The reward was to get your name on the silver replica of a mustering billy, the old-fashioned wide-bottomed pot with a mug which fitted inside to form a lid, and was boiled, when time permitted, hanging from the end of a mustering stick over a hastily-lit fire. <i>(1980,Tussock Ranges,203</i>)

>  <b>STRONACH</b> We halted at the Saxon for a boil. Each filled his small mustering billy and held it over the fire on the end of the mustering stick. <i>(1953,Musterer on Molesworth,8</i>)



## mustering boots
 
 <i>n.</i>

>  <b>LANGDALE-HUNT</b> Some of the oil (black fish or bottle-nosed grampus) was still in the workshop in my time, until my brother, Reg tried it out on his mustering boots one day and was begged ... to leave them outside because they made her feel ill. <i>(1985,Last Entail Male,25</i>)



## mustering camp
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a makeshift overnight shelter for musterers, [usually consisting of tents and tussock beds.]

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> In the old mustering camps, the dog tucker was usually wild pig. <i>(1940,Te Waimate,120</i>)

>  <b>ACLAND</b> <i>(1930,Early Canterbury Runs,138</i>)

>  <b>STUDHOLME</b> Well, out on the old mustering camps, we used to say 'A horse that carries the Bell brand will carry you till he drops.' <i>(1940,Te Waimate,6</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> At an old mustering camp on the fringe of the bush we ran into one of the Departmental packmen. <i>(1952,High Country Journey,179</i>)

## mustering country
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) land that is steep, in very large blocks, and carrying few stock to the hectare.

>  <b>FOSTER & WRIGHT</b> Mustering country, the country of the stockman, appears to be changing so quickly that there's barely time to notice what's happening. <i>(1983,Stockman Country,152</i>)



## mustering dog
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a sheepdog trained to muster, hunt and head sheep.

>  .. Rose, also a black brindle, was a very useful, handy bitch destined to become one of the famed mustering dogs for that part of Canterbury. <i>(Apr 11, 1968,NZ Farmer,45</i>)

>  <i>Sheep dog</i>.- Dog to work sheep; <i>collie</i> (q.v.). <i>S.ds.</i> run naturally either to bring sheep towards you or to drive them away; and when a puppy shows his preference he is broken in for that work. The dogs that bring sheep are called <i>heading ds</i>. (q.v.) and most of these can be taught to <i>lead</i> (q.v.) if desired. Dogs which take to driving sheep away are broken in to <i>huntaway</i> and are called <i>htwys</i> (q.v.). Some dogs will both<i> hd</i>. and <i>htwy</i> and are called <i>handy ds</i>. They are not generally high-class heading dogs but very useful about hand and sometimes very useful mustering dogs. Some men have a special <i>slewing d</i>., but a well-trained, <i>hdg</i>. dog or <i>htwy</i>. will usually <i>slew</i> (q.v.). (C.) <i>(Nov 25, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  Sheep dogs are of three distinct classes - the show dog, or fancy-worker, the mustering or paddock dog, and the yard or forcing dog. <i>(Mar 1907,NZ Farmer,209</i>)

>  The utility dog is a different class of animal. He is of two kinds - the mustering dog and the yard dog. <i>(1907,NZ Farmer,210</i>)

>  This great strain is known for noise, their terrific stamina and strong running qualities as mustering dogs. <i>(Sep 28, 1961,NZ Farmer,71</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> .. a man who always keeps a first class team of mustering dogs. <i>(1969,Big Country of the North Island,32</i>)

>  <b>ASPINALL</b> Unfortunately I lost several good mustering dogs. <i>(1993,Farming Under Aspiring,228</i>)



## mustering gang
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a team of musterers. (See [hill gang; mountain gang](../H#hill-gang;-mountain-gang))

>  <b>NEWTON</b> On the average station, the mustering gang consists of the 'Boss,' a head shepherd - a permanent station employee - and four to six musterers. There is also a packman who packs, on horses, the men's bed rolls and rations, and who does the cooking. <i>(1947,Wayleggo,13</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> For many years St Helens kept a man at the accommodation house, and one of his jobs was baking the bread for the two mustering gangs. <i>(1973,Big Country of the South Island,66</i>)

>  <b>MCLEOD</b> On the larger stations the mustering gang and other more or less permanent hands will number seven to ten ... <i>(1951,NZ High Country,10</i>)

>  <b>SHARPE</b> If it happened to a mustering gang on a sheep station, the owner would have a blue fit ... <i>(1966,Fiordland Muster,227</i>)

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> team: in a mustering gang, each man has a team of dogs - never, never a 'pack' of them. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,84</i>)



## mustering hut
 
 <i>n.</i> [cf. shepherd's hut] (See [also musterers' hut](../A#also-musterers'-hut))

>  <i>Mustering Hut.</i>- More often simply <i>hut.</i> Built out on a run for men to camp in, it is usually of one room with a fire-place, table, bench, and bunks round the sides.(C.) <i>(Nov 4, 1933,Press, The,15</i>) [NOTES: Acland Glossary]

>  <b>CRESSWELL</b> ... the next night we reached one of the mustering-huts near the head waters of the Rangitata ... <i>(1939,Present Without Leave,188</i>)

>  <b>HARPER</b> Paul Thomson was sent in from a mustering hut one day to collect more cheese ... <i>(1975,Eight Daughters,77</i>)
