## mustering plan
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a map and/or discussion showing locations and beats of musters on large stations.

>  <b>EVANS</b> The Hunter Hills country was divided into four areas known as the first, second, third and fourth spurs. When mustering plans were considered, these names were used to guide the musterers as to which area was to be worked on. <i>(1975,Silver Tussock, The,9</i>)



## mustering pole
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) a long thin stick made of manuka or other hard wood to support a musterer on the tops. (See [hillpole](../H#hillpole))

>  <b>PASCOE</b> In the afternoon they camped, lashed blankets to their mustering poles by the side of a large rock ... <i>(1959,Great Days in NZ Exploration,89</i>)

>  Mustering stick: mustering pole. <i>(2001,Questionnaire Respondents (DB)</i>)



## mustering season
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) the six months when mustering gangs are employed to work, usually from November to April.

>  <b>FERNANDEZ</b> Off they all flew, Barbara a match for the men on her eager pony, for although the station hacks were bigger, perhaps stronger, more exercised, they were also somewhat weary after the long mustering season. <i>(1973,Tussock Fever,7</i>)

>  <b>PYKE</b> Never was he happier than ... when, as at mustering [57] seasons, madly galloping over the plains, he chased the wild cattle, waking the echoes with the crack of the long stockman's whip, which none could more dexterously [sic] flourish than he. <i>(1873,Wild Will Enderby,2/iii/56-57,1889, 1974 ed.</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> Besides Ray Birdsall there are nine musterers and shepherds, the majority of them there only for the mustering season. <i>(1969,Big Country of the North Island,29</i>)

>  <b>COATES</b> I had only one mustering season there but between musters I was kept on as boundary rider and other station work. <i>(1995,Dining With the Cats,103</i>)



## mustering station
 
<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) an outstation, used mainly by shepherds and musterers.

>  <b>KEENE</b> Te Paki was the home of Yates' son-in-law, A R Crane, who managed the sheep station, while Tapotupotu was a mustering station on the coast where there was a house erected and lived in for a time by Stannus Jones of Auckland before it was taken over by musterers. <i>(1977,To the Northward,88</i>)



## mustering stick
 
 <i>n.</i> (Rural) a long stick, usually made of manuka [used by a musterer on steep shingle or sidlings and for crossing swift mountain rivers and jumping creeks.] (See [hillpole](../H#hillpole),[hillstick](../H#hillstick),[mustering pole](../M#mustering-pole),[nibbie](../N#nibbie),[rakau](../R#rakau))

>  <b>LOUGHNAN</b> micky-mick: corruption of the Maori name mingiming (Coprosma propinqua) a native shrub which will yield excellent mustering sticks, which in some quarters are preferred even to manuka. <i>(1981,Loughnan Glossary,53</i>)

>  <b>STACEY</b> By using my mustering stick as a tail skid it was possible to take giant strides down moving shingle and drop down a thousand feet in a few minutes. [mustering stick] <i>(1996,Tales of a Tussock Jumper,71</i>)

>  <b>MCLEOD</b> Mustering sticks are usually nearly shoulder high .. manuka is the commonest wood, but Miki-miki and Hazel are sometimes used. <i>(1951,NZ High Country,24</i>)

>  <b>MACNICOL</b> Archie's mustering stick was exchanged for a shepherd's crook, and his packhorses for a tractor ... <i>(1965,Beyond the Skippers Road,158</i>)

>  <b>ROBERTSON</b> When the gang arrived for tea we had to thread a rope through the tents, tie the rope ends to a bush and use the mustering sticks to raise the tents off the ground, then crawl in on hands and knees. <i>(1986,Century at Waitangi Station, A,49</i>)



 
 <i>n.</i> (See [also musterer's stick](../A#also-musterer's-stick))

>  <b>McLEOD</b> ... with his long mustering stick in his hand, he has a walking beat. ... Mustering sticks are usually nearly shoulder high and must be strong and tough and not too heavy. >  <b>DUFF</b> In <i>A Musterer on Molesworth</i> Bruce Stronach says that his dogs learnt in a few days to eat and sleep tied in a circle round his mustering stick, ... <i>(Jan 27, 1954,Shepherd's Calendar,161,1961 ed.</i>)

>  <b>STRONACH</b> [each one] held it over the fire on the end of the mustering stick, which is a stout staff about six feet long. Mustering sticks are generally of manuka wood, [9] unobtainable on the station. <i>(1953,Musterer on Molesworth,8</i>)

>  <b>MASTERS</b> ... Hermit lay down on the trip and refused to move until Fred had given him several good jabs with the end of his mustering stick, ... <i>(1960,Back-Country Tales,126</i>)

>  <b>NEWTON</b> <i>Mustering Stick</i>: When on the hill, high-country musterers carry a long walking-stick. Also referred to as a nibby or pole. <i>(1966,Boss's Story, The,188</i>)

>  <b>BRUCE</b> To test [the ice] out he sent his mustering stick [101] down to see if it would stop in this lip or cup. <i>(1977,Life in the Hinterland of the South Island,100</i>)

>  <b>HENDERSON</b> We soon learned to prod with our mustering sticks into suspicious-looking mounds of snow in places where sheep naturally would huddle for shelter. <i>(1965,Open Country Harvest,189</i>) [NOTES: From 1970 edition]

 <i>n.</i>

## mustering yard

<b>1</b> <i>n.</i> (Rural) the joining of all mobs of a muster into one large mob.

 <i>n.</i> a sheep

>  <b>McLINTOCK</b> MUTTONBIRD. Also known as the sooty shearwater or titi, the New Zealand muttonbird is <i>Puffinus griseus</i> and belongs to the order of sea birds known as petrels. As a name, `muttonbird' appears to have originated among early European settlers in Australasia and is said to refer to the taste of the flesh. At least as probable is the theory that the name refers to the rather woolly appearance of the downy young. In New Zealand other petrels are also given the name `muttonbird'. In fact, the sooty shearwater, which is most abundant on the islands about Foveaux Strait, might well be called the <i>southern</i> muttonbird, and the grey-faced petrel, predominant on the islands off the coast of Auckland Province,the <i>northern</i> muttonbird. In Victoria, Tasmania, Bass Strait, and South Australia, the species is the short-tailed shearwater - an occasional visitor to New Zealand seas. <i>(1966,Encyclopaedia of New Zealand, An,2/616</i>)
